description:
We all have our idiosyncrasies. Some more than others. Some more... eccentric than others. I'd probably fall into the latter category, though I wouldn't mind being in both. One of my quirks is an admittedly irrational aversion to saying such words as boing, plop, bomb and Filbert. Luckily, Yelp is text based, so writing the word Filbert isn't an issue for me. Therefore, I'm able to write this review without counseling and medication. The Hanalei Island IPA at my elbow isn't medicinal, I consider it my muse. 

Writing a review about a staircase seems a bit... daft. Why not review the escalator at Westminster Mall? No, not the one by Cinnabon. The one over by Victoria's Secret. Seems more alluring, somehow. Or I could write a review about the elevator at Cafe Coyote in Old Town San Diego. So damn slow!

Now, there is something about the Filbert Steps that does set it apart from other staircases, stairwells, escalators, elevators and handicap access ramps. It's freaking gorgeous! Does that sound too.... flamboyant? Not that there's anything wrong with that!!

Basically, it's a staircase leading up to Coit Tower atop Telegraph Hill. Parking at the Coit is available, but almost pointless. May as well perform a self-vasectomy with a rubber mallet. There are other ways to get there, but Filbert Steps is a trek through a dazzling, lush garden, tended to by the residents who live astride the path. It is a bit steep, so can be strenuous, but take it at a leisurely pace, enjoying the foliage and the views overlooking the bay. It's a bit of an unknown secret to tourists. I highly recommend Filberting up to the Coit!!
author: Michael H.

description:
A workout in San Francisco...

Ann S. suggested that we go here for the view. 
I had bookmarked it and we were in the area.  We finally found it with our GPS - at Filbert and Sansome. 

Gosh...I didn't realize how many (steel) steps up there are - over 400?!  Kudos to those who climb up to Coit Tower!  

We were tired and hungry, so we will leave this for another day!  It just looked very overwhelming!
author: Nadine C.

description:
Yes. If you're going to San Francisco put this one on the list. There are dozens of stairs to climb; this is one of the best.

Without a doubt you will see more tourist than locals but this is not a tourist trap. Far from it. It's not crowded and it truly beautiful with all the greenery and parrots! It's the views though that are worth the hike.

This is a strenuous urban hike. If your not in great shape or over 50 it's a tough one but a must do. Maybe simply start at the top and Uber from the bottom back!

Do it!
author: Justin S.

description:
Filbert Steps are flights of stairs that take you all the way up from Sansome Street (near Levi's Corporate Headquarters) to Coit Tower. Expect lengthy steps (took us 15 minutes to get to Coit Tower), various public gardens (including Grace Marchant Garden which named after a resident who dedicated her time to beautify the wooden Filbert Steps back in late 1940's), hidden residential houses, and wild parrots (I didn't get to hear any of them). I was surprised by how lengthy these steps were, but hey at least it was an excellent work out. These stairs also have handrails, so you can grab them if you have some fear of heights.

Unlike The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps and Lyon Street Steps, you won't have too many opportunities to take bird-eye scenic pictures on Filbert Steps due to surrounding trees. Even if you reach to the designed viewing area outside of Coit Tower, these same trees prevent you from taking breathtaking 360-view pictures (I feel like someone did this intentionally so that visitors are forced to pay and go up to Coit Tower for panoramic pictures). 

Overall a great steps for exercise and gardens, but there are better steps for better city views.

P.S. - Greenwich Street Stairs are in parallel with Filbert Steps. So you can make a loop to go up and down.
author: Luke L.

description:
These stairs are definitely urban hiking at it's best.  

Be warned that it is a workout.  There are spots where you can stop and rest but use them as an opportunity to turn around and get a good look at the view.  It's incredible, especially on a clear beautiful day.  And bring water!  I failed to do this and suffered a little.  

The gardens tended by the residents here are amazing!  You can tell they really love their neighborhood.  I haven't seen a passion flower in a long time so it was great to be able to bask in the glory of these gardens.  

I read somewhere to take the Filbert St Steps up (and continue up Telegraph Hill to Coit Tower) and take the Greenwich St Steps down (if you happen to be headed back that way) and not the other way around.  I'm sure glad we did this because the Greenish St ones are much steeper and slightly dicier.  There were a few loose steps that scared me a little.  It actually hurt both our knees a little to go down these steps.  However, if you're looking for a harder workout, do it!
author: Christina R.

description:
The Filbert steps were everything I hoped for. I read other reviews before I took the trip. It was actually Yep they gave me the idea to trot up the steps.
We went on a Thursday so they were not too crowded. Our trip was perfect weather wise.  The views are amazing.
And all the trees a little houses that you get To walk by are so serene.  
And my favorite thing that I did not realize Coit Tower is at the top.
Recommend the filbert steps Highly.
author: Anita V.

description:
I've been on a few "step" walks around SF and I would rate Filbert Steps as one of my favorites so far.  It has views, gardens, flowers, lush foliage, a nice mix of sun & shade, quaint homes, isn't too crowded, and is a nice workout.  Check, check, and check.  

We made the uphill trek from Sansome & Filbert all the way to Coit Tower.  As you walk the steps, you'll see lovely views of the Bay and the Bay Bridge.  We frequently passed jogging locals and tourists, but it wasn't overly crowded (on a Saturday afternoon).  It's a pleasant walk, considering most of the area lacks any traffic (no car access) and there was a nice mix of sun and shade to the path.  There was at least one lovely garden and you certainly notice the lush foliage along the path - one might forget and think you're in the tropics and no longer in SF.   The wooden steps added to the aesthetics as well.  

Tips:
-If you're walking along Embarcadero/piers, it's about a 6 or 7 minute walk from Pier 19 (you head West).

-If you want to walk uphill, start at Filbert & Sansome.  If you prefer to go downhill, you can start at Coit Tower and head East.  I'm not sure if parking will be an issue; and, for the directionally challenged, it could be hard for you to find the path to Filbert Steps from Coit.  I noticed several trails going out of Coit Tower.  As an alternative, you can start at Montgomery and Filbert as well (if you want to avoid Coit Tower parking and have a shorter walk).  I think you can also park further West of Coit on Filbert if you want a longer descending walk (see Google Maps).  

-If you're relatively unfit, this may be hard for you (going uphill).  I saw one lady who seemed to struggle not too far into the walk.  Our group's fitness level ranged from below average to average and we did OK on the hike.  It helped since we stopped periodically to admire the scenery, which allowed us to rest.  Bring water as there are a lot of steps.  There are handrails for most of the path for those curious.  

-The start of the steps (near Filbert & Sansome) is minutes away from Levi Plaza.  Levi's Plaza has their company HQ, a Levi store, a man-made waterfall, and benches.  The main building which houses the store does have bathrooms inside by security (if you need to pee before or after your hike).  Right across Battery Street is Levi's Plaza Park that's a small, clean park.  

-If you'd like to stop & picnic before/after your walk, you can do so at Levi Plaza Park (bottom of the hike) or at Coit Tower (top of the hike).  Along the hike, there were a few spots to stop off and rest or admire the views, but nowhere to really sit or do a proper picnic.
author: Laura C.

description:
If you feel like you've completely exhausted your San Francisco to-do list (believe me, it can happen quickly whether or not you actually live here), there's always the stairways. While searching through different lists of "off-the-beaten" things to do in the city, I came across the Filbert Steps. Filbert Steps is one of 8 different stairways that can be found throughout San Francisco (see more here: http://www.sftourismtips.com/stairways-of-san-francisco.html). Basically, due to the hilly nature of SF, there are going to be some opportunities for architects to use their creativity and construct beautiful steps that carry people from one street to another. The steps on Filbert Street is one such creation. 

Filbert Steps, as indicated by the name, is located on Filbert Street perpendicular to Sansome Street. The really amazing thing about this stairway (as well as the other 7 in SF), is that it really does serve a purpose. Essentially, these steps allow direct access from the bottom of Sansom Street, to the top on Montgomery Street. And so they'll be TONS of people going through Filbert Steps each day, whether for commuting purposes, working out, or even for tourism...

...and the last part is definitely true because Filbert Steps is GORGEOUS! My girlfriend and I decided to venture out and explore the steps as part of our whirlwind tour through San Francisco's lesser-known landmarks. If you have any desire to come, I highly recommend you take public transportation, as parking can be REALLY bad. Filbert Steps is located close to the Pier/Union Square and so chances are you may have to pay. There are some free spots (free on weekends) next to the base of the steps, but they may be taken up. 

Let me preface by saying that Filbert Steps is truly a workout, especially if you don't exercise. Because remember, you're climbing up one of the steeper hills in San Francisco. Especially during the first part near Sansome, you are going to be climbing very high. I'd tread slowly if you have a fear of heights because it may get gnarly. But, the view is WORTH IT. It's not even that you get a great view of the Bay. Once you are in the middle of Filbert Street, you can get a glimpse of all the beautiful gardens and greenery that residents on the hill maintain. Yep, people actually live on Filbert Street. It's pretty cool! 

The end destination of Filbert Street is Montgomery Street, where Telegraph Hill begins. This is actually a really nice area both because Coit Tower is there and also because you might see some parrots (https://www.yelp.com/biz/the-parrots-of-telegraph-hill-san-francisco)!!! 

Overall, I give Filbert Steps an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this" rating. It's such a tranquil and transformative experience, both mentally and physically. More often than not, this area will be very quiet. And so it's a great opportunity to work out those legs and enjoy the view that San Francisco has to offer!

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
If you like walks, or pretty flowers, or fresh air, or SF, or if you are reading this right now, then you should probably grab a friend and walk the Filbert Steps. 

On an otherwise overcast day, the sun was shining on Levi's Plaza where we began our ascent (Filbert & Sansome). Looking up, the trek looked formidable; I took some NSAIDs for my bum knee. But much to my relief, the steps had numerous lookout points at short intervals where you could take a breather and enjoy the gardens. 

The gardens themselves are definitely instagram worthy. Think more country cottage than manicured  grounds. Try to see which varieties you can name. Nasturtium, angel trumpets, and foxgloves for me. Multiple varieties of roses and some fruit trees as well.

We also got a cool sighting of the famous Telegraph Hill parrots. They chattered and swooped above the amazing architecture and settled into the palm trees.

On a Friday afternoon, we only bumped into a handful of other people. We stopped often to admire and take photos and it still only took us about 20min to make it to Coit Tower. From there, you can branch off to North Beach or Chinatown to continue your walk. 

I live here and I'll definitely keep coming back to play tourist and to check out the changing of the seasons in the gardens.
author: K G.

description:
My little girl has been looking forward to one of our mother-daughter adventures here so we celebrated our school-free summer by tackling this walk.  
We began our walk early as we got off at Embarcadero BART(Montgomery BART may be closer).  When we got to Levi's Plaza, we saw the sign indicating "steps to Coit Tower."  After sliding past a sleeping man, we began our journey.  The gardens are beautiful and lush. The noises of a busy city fall away as you climb higher. We didn't hear or see the parrots though my daughter hoped every chirp and squawk she heard meant they still live here. Once you get to the bottom of Coit Tower, you can visit the landmark or head downhill into North Beach . We did both. This is definitely worth a visit especially since you can treat yourself to Italian deliciousness as a reward. 

Tie on your sneaks, bring a water bottle, and dress in layers.  It may be a tourist treat but it's also a legit workout.  Make sure to pause to take in amazing views of the Bay Bridge and Embarcadero.
author: Julie C.

description:
Filbert Steps are KILLER! Looking for an amazing workout? Just visit Filbert Steps for an hour. I promise it'll give you a full body workout that'll leave you feeling sweaty, sore and accomplished. 

The steps are steel, don't play it cheap. Wear comfortable shoes that offer stability on the steel, wood & concrete pavements. Again, these are very steel and winding. There is railing for your support. Trash cans to keep the area immaculate, alarms for fire & police should you need assistance and epic views. 

Take your camera and capture the moments, I did.
~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
Climbing the Filbert steps is one of my favorite things to do in the city...besides eat. But climb the steps and then you'll have a great excuse to eat more!

The stairs wend up a hill to Coit tower, past beautiful little homes nestled into the hillside with lush gardens and really interesting doors and gates. 

Don't forget to stop and turn around periodically for some really stunning views of the Bay. 

They are a bit steep, but I've done them quite a few times with little kids and they've always managed.
author: Dara M.

description:
My kids went. I stayed behind. 

Even staring up at them made my heart flutter. 

I am afraid of heights. It was just.. "Hell-no!"

Pro Tip: there is parking and a short walk to Pier 39.
author: Tram N.

description: What a gem of a walk! If you're active and want to do your own walking tour through unusual places, go here! You get to walk through lush green gardens that are the neighbourhood backyards so to speak. Lots of stairs so you're going to get a good workout! This is one of the green walking routes to and from Coit Tower.
author: Shirley C.

description:
Last month, on a typical lazy Sunday, while Wifey and I were at Half Moon Bay, we drove to the city to squeeze more activity for the weekend. I told her, "Let's climbs some stairs" and to my surprise, she agreed. 

I placed the directions on the Waze app and drove here and found parking easily since it was on a Sunday. 

We looked at the stairs and thought, "How bad could this be?" since we are hikers. Well, the first part of the stairs is a pretty steep incline and by the time I got to the top part of the concrete steps before the wooden stairs begin, I was huffing and puffing like a dog in heat. We had to stop and catch our breaths and was surprised with the difficulty we were having. 

As we ascended the wooden steps, there was a nice garden on the left called Grace Merchant Garden named after a resident who lived on Napier Lane, a woodplanked road along the steps. She started cleaning up the place as that part of the steps became on informal garbage dump and the garden was named in her honor. It's a nice area to enjoy the different plants and flowers (as well as a Banana tree) and if you're lucky, you'll run in to the resident cat. (That cat is the friendliest cat I ever met and such a sweetie.) 

As we came upon Montgomery, the wooden steps ended and the concrete steps began all the way up to Coit Tower. We stopped there to catch the view of the Bay and the Transamerica Pyramid on the left. Who am I kidding, we stopped because we wanted to rest and catch our breaths again. As soon as got our wind back, we made our way up to more stairs leading to the back of Coit Tower. 

It took us about 20 minutes and some spare change to make our way to the top and we were both winded. We did enjoy the view on top though and had to the descend back down the stairs, which is not my favorite part. It's easier for me to walk up the stairs than climb back down due to my knee surgeries.

From that day, Wifey said she wanted to return to the steps to get back in shape and we have been doing so after work for several weeks now. We don't go everyday, but sometimes I would walk there to meet here as we had made it quite a routine. From 20 minutes, I made improvements to 15, then 9, then 8 minutes. My current fastest is 7 minutes and my goal is 5 minutes. I don't know if I can break that marker, I might have to jog up the steps in order to achieve that, but I'll keep trying. Heck, there's even an Asian lady probably in her late 50's who goes up and down the steps like it was a piece of cake for her. 

In a nutshell, Filbert Steps is another one of those local spots that you can get a workout on while enjoying the great view of the city and the bay.
author: John G.

description: A beautiful little stairway to heaven, as my guidebook pointed out. And I couldn't agree more. It's definitely leaving you out of breath, so definitely take your time, take a few little breaks in between, turn around and enjoy the view, especially when it's a sunny day. You have the Bay and Bay Bridge in the distance, but also the houses and gardens along the path are just gorgeous. So many colorful flowers. I almost wish I lived here, but then again, do I really want to climb those stairs every day? Probably not, but I will be back and it's getting a spot on my "When friends & family are in town" list.
author: Katja S.

description: WOW are these steps STEEP. I wasn't quite prepared for how many flights of stairs this is, but it's worth checking out at least once. The Coit Tower is at the top, and I would say it takes at least 15 minutes to climb all the way up if you're going at an easy pace and taking a break here or there. I climbed up on a Friday afternoon, and it wasn't too busy at that time. It's super scenic along the way, and you get to admire the SF architecture as well as the awesome views of the Bay. I'd definitely recommend checking these steps out at least once, but be prepared for the workout!
author: Amy D.

description:
We stumbled upon these steps. Get it? Stumbled. Sorry. 

We were trying to get to Coit Tower from the Embarcadero and these steps became a part of our route. What a pleasant surprise. This is the route that everyone should take, regardless if they are trying to go to the Coit Tower or not.

These steep steps wind through a coy neighborhood on a hill. Different levels represent streets and the mail-person who navigates these addresses must have calves of steel. The long haul to the top is so worth it. If you take breaks during your climb you will see great views of the Oakland Bay Bridge through the lavish overhanging trees. 

Filbert Steps are a must try and are even better to find as a surprise.
author: Rawlins R.

description:
Climbing or descending the Filbert Steps is a must do in San Francisco, and it's FREE. Obviously, San Francisco is known for its steps and hills and this climb is absolutely beautiful.  The stairs rise in three separate sections which is great because you can pretend to take pictures while resting at the top of each section - like my kids.  The ascension is wonderful, so why not take your time.  Beautiful art deco houses adorn both sides of the steps, the gardens are colorful and well tended and there are turns, nooks and crannies along the way. The great thing about the journey is that world famous Coit Tower, one of San Francisco's most cherished landmarks is the final destination.  If done properly, you can knock two landmarks off your 'to do' list at one time. 

I would recommend bringing some water, and maybe lunch for a "bench picnic" on your stair adventure.  It goes without saying that you should bring a camera because the views of the Bay Bridge, Treasury Island, Coit Tower and Levi Plaza are spectacular.

Put in the physical effort, the visual stimuli is well worth it!
author: Chris G.

description:
I fantasize living in one of these cute cottages that lines up on Filbert street steps.  Who wouldn't love living on the hillside with lush greens growing happily and freely, parrots chirping in the summer sun, million dollar views of San Francisco, and be cardio fit?  If only I won the lottery.  If only one was selling for my price range.  If only... if only... ahhh... it's just a fantasy to live here.  

I find that these stairs are easier to climb up than the Greenwich stairs.  I know because of how my lungs feel after the climb up and usually, I'm more out of breath on the Greenwich stairs than the Filbert stairs.  But either way, it's a really good workout and if your super fit, it should only take you less than 15 minutes to climb from Levi's plaza to the top of Coit Tower.  But for people like myself?  Take plenty of breaks so that you can make it to the top!
author: Jenny T.

description:
It may not be at the top of your tourist to do list, but walking the Filbert Steps is interesting and one of those things that gets you up close and personal with the city.  After visiting Coit Tower we found the steps on the back side at the corner of Filbert and Telegraph.  We encountered people walking up the stairs including some who were huffing and puffing.  I laughed to myself and thought, "You're going the wrong way."  Believe me, it's very steep if you walk up.  Do yourself a favor and walk down the steps.  It will be more enjoyable.  When walking down, you end up at Levi Plaza, steps away from the Embarcadero.    

Along the way we came across gorgeous gardens, unique architecture plus some great views.  We even heard squawking from the parrots of Telegraph Hill as they flew about, but any glimpses were fleeting.  Perhaps the most fascinating thing was finding street signs and fire hydrants where there were no streets.  Homes along the steps aren't accessible by car, only by walking in.  That plays with your mind in so many ways.  Everything in anyone's house was carried in.  Think about that when you see a baby grand piano in the front window! 

It's worth the time to walk the steps and experience one of San Francisco's quirky, unique adventures.
author: Will T.

description:
Doesn't look that far to Coit tower.

Don't be fooled! A beautiful, heart-pounding walk thru gardens up the hill. Awesome views and it's free! Be mindful of the private property signs!

I didn't make it to the top ...... this time!
author: Eric J.

description: Wow!  can't believe it took me this long to come here.  I have probably walked by this stairway entrance a thousand times since moving to SF and never knew it was there.  If you are looking for a quick cardio burst with breathtaking views then look no further.  I plan on coming back here very soon!
author: Halley S.

description:
It's very likely that somewhere between Chinatown and the top of the Filbert Steps, I died. I knew it was steep and that there was an intense climb, but man, it was intense. None-the-less, I was successful. And these steps were actually really awesome instead of the steep street that was less measured.

The steps themselves are extremely picturesque with a view of lovely homes and the San Francisco skyline, even better since maybe you haven't even seen the Coit Tower yet!
author: Bruce K.

description:
I honestly had no idea that staircases had names. Heck, I had no idea that I was on THE Filbert Steps when I was climbing up.

Awesome name for stairs, we used these stairs to get to the top of Coit Tower. It was a mission, but it was worth it, every step of the way. I can't believe people live up here, so many stairs, they must be super healthy! But other than that, these stairs are very well maintained and were honestly beautiful and made of wood. Many houses grow nice flowers beside it. 

It felt like 350 stairs to the top, but from reading other people's reviews, there are about 400-500 steps, GREAT WORKOUT IDEA. Everyone should take Filbert Steps one day and enjoy the awesome view!
author: Kristy N.

description: If you're planning to go visit coit tower, this is the perfect excursion to make right before. Filbert steps is a hidden gem in SF. As an SF native, I'm not quite sure why I've never been here until this past weekend. The stairs are quite intense and whether you're looking for a good workout or simply feel the need to escape the city for a bit, the step can provide just that. Nestled amongst trees, flowers, and garlands, you walk passed houses resembling cute cottages. I felt like I was in a scene in the secret gardens. Part of the stairs is wood and the other metal. I would highly suggest only coming during the day time and enjoying the views.  Of course, respect the residences that live along the steps. Great place.
author: Diane T.

description:
Filbert Steps and Greenwich Steps are both great ways to get up to and down from Coit Tower.  Some of the steps are very steep, especially the ones at the bottom, so it is not for the faint of heart.  What I enjoy about the steps is that because it goes right through private residences, you will run into the people who live there walking their dogs and they are happy to tell you about the history of the neighborhood.  They are generally very friendly and not annoyed by tourism, or in my case...localism?  My favorite Saturday routine is to go up one of these steps, enjoy the view at the top, come down the other steps, and then walk to the Ferry Building to shop at the farmers' market.  This loop makes me love San Francisco.

Oh I heard there are also parrots on these steps.  I have never seen or heard any, but apparently that is a thing.  I hope I am wrong, because I don't want some high-pitched creature yelling at me.  I get enough of that from my family.  Sorry, it is Thanksgiving time and I am anticipating a lot of high-pitched creatures this week.
author: Ally W.

description:
Came here and climbed the steps a month ago... I'm still out of breath.

Me on the first set of steps: So fun! Can't believe I haven't been here before! Let's go to the farmer's market and do this every weekend! 

Me on the last set of steps: F*ck these steps. 

Its beautiful, for sure, but be ready for a solid layer of sweat to surround your body after the second or third flight. I work out every day and my calves were shaking on the way up and even worse on the way back down. 

Spectacular views and unlike anywhere else. Great little semi-grueling (if you aren't ready for it) walk up to Coit Tower and the next time I'm not in heels and more prepared with a sports bra I'll gladly take this residential hike again.
author: Candice G.

description:
This is written mainly for the tourists who are looking for something in Everybody's Favorite City that is not the usual same-ol same-ol.

The Filbert Steps are in a part of San Francisco that not many people go to.  Not a lot of reason to go to the end of Sansome Street unless you're at your job at Levi's Plaza.  The intervening three blocks are all residential.  Parking is terrible, naturally.

But when you go onto the steps, you don't know if you're in Sitka AK or Olympia WA.

Big trees, and mature greenery all around.  Housing ranging from humble to spectacular.  Many places to sit, or you can sit on the steps.  No tourists, few locals, and the birds are louder than the traffic.  Then you look east, and you see a view of San Francisco Bay that gets better the higher you climb.

"Climb", that's the operative word.  These are steep stairs, and are not for the out-of-shape.  It is not recommended as a shortcut to Coit Tower unless you know you can make it up even one block.  Or you can do these stairs *because* you are out of shape;  do this 2-3 times per week for an only-in-San-Francisco aerobic exercise.  You'll be in shape before long.  Be extremely careful on the way down, it's easy to lose control.

The Filbert Steps are quite a jaunt from the Financial District.  But I've done it.  A totally Ron story:  I left my job on Market Street for a lunch break, grabbed my lunch sack, and walked to the Filbert Steps.  If I remember right, it took 20 brisk minutes, and the road is mostly flat.  I went 1-1/2 blocks upstairs, until I had a gorgeous view.  Then I sat down, enjoying the peace and quiet, grabbed my sandwich . . . and found that I had grabbed somebody else's lunch.

The Filbert Steps are the best way to get to Coit Tower while getting your exercise.
author: Ron L.

description:
Looking to see Coit Tower but want a different way to get there, then head up the Filbert Steps a literal hidden gem of San Francisco.

Located on the "backside" Coit tower these steps will either lead you down from the Tower to Levi's Plaza or visa versa.  Which ever way you decide to take these steps you are in for a treat as the steps (steep in either direction) take you through some pretty lovely views both of the canopied gardens that line either sides of the steps and some pretty spectacular views of the San Francisco Bay.

So glad I stumbled upon these steps - it was still a workout heading down the steep incline but I loved the fact that I had stumbled upon something that few know about. 

Although I am hesitant to share my discovery for fear the Filbert Steps will become more congested and touristy, I loved them so much that I know only those looking for something off the beaten path will read this review and attempt to find this hidden gem!
author: Anne C.

description: Climbing these steps made me question my own fitness.  600 steps! I kid you not, they are conquerable.  You might be tired, you might hate your life, but you will not regret making it to the top.  The views are gorgeous.  Just past the Levi campus, you'll find the Filbert Steps leading up to Coit Tower.  You'll pass many homes and gardens wondering how on Earth people move into these hilly homes while trying to catch your breath.  The path isn't exactly one set of staircases but many.  Enjoy the views!
author: Trina D.

description:
For anybody planning on visiting Coit tower, I would recommend taking the 15 minutes to climb up the Filbert steps.  It's great exercise and you get to admire some scenic views and cool neighborhoods on the way, tacitly avoiding getting in the way of/gossiping about the people who actually live in these houses.  
There are some beautiful gardens on the way, as well as increasingly better views of the bay and gradually, Coit tower starts peeking over.  There is lots of available parking both at the lot directly near the base and at the meters lining the streets.  Great place!
author: Emily Y.

description: Lots of amazing views from the Filbert Steps and good exercise at that! I walked up the Greenwich Steps (which I prefer) to Coit Tower then down the Filbert Steps. Tons of greenery and lovely houses to see along the way. No clue why I rate steps on Yelp except to make their existence clear. I really do prefer the Greenwich Steps if you had to choose one (but por que no los dos) and I heard that there are parrots nearby so check them out!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I love the Filbert Steps!  Usually on my weekends in SF,  I have this loop that I walk around the FiDi and North Beach area where I have the long way taking the Embarcadero all the way to Fisherman's Wharf to get to North Beach and back to the FiDi..  But on some weekends when the weather is gorgeous outside, and when my testicular fortitude kicks in, I like to take a shortcut and use the Filbert Steps to get to North Beach instead.

It's pretty incredible and also a great workout walking up these steps which lead you to the bottom of Coit Tower.  The first part is kind of scary though since it's a hollow set of metal steps where you can the view underneath each step (http://bit.ly/1txKedW).  But along the way you pass through all these gardens and trees that are very scenic and make the trek up the steps more inviting (http://bit.ly/1l50DWz).  And when you finally reach the Coit Tower, you get rewarded to probably one of the best views in all of San Francisco (http://bit.ly/1ojySVo).

The Filbert Steps is one of those "hiddem gems" in SF that doesn't get much publicity, but it's really a great spot to show off to your out-of-town friends and relatives.  Everyone I've taken up the steps with me had a great time!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Oh my lovely lord.  This is my new absolute favorite thing in San Francisco. 

Yes, it's an uphill climb. But you will stop plenty of times on the way up, trust me.  The beauty of the gardens that are tended here is so incredible.  If the gardens don't get you, the view as you climb up the hill will.  Or perhaps you'll see a parrot!  A pedal cab driver described this to me as "an oxygen bath", and he was so right. 

You'll see ginger, you'll see trumpet flowers, you'll see banana trees, you'll see every beautiful flower imaginable.  Also the homes along this way are the most charming - I am so jealous!  You might run across a few charming cats, as well.  Please respect the neighbors, but check this out at least once!
author: Johanna K.

description:
My friends, my friends, where for art thou?

I was certain that upon taking keyboard in hand I'd be greeted by my smiling horde, all of you already pronouncing on this special place.  But, oddly, not so much.

Let me then be your introduction.  Let me then urge you to one fine summer SF day this year make yourself a little detour off the waterfront or up the hill from North Beach or maybe even simply out of your way from someplace across town - check this vertical park.  It isn't a place to tarry so much, because a fortunate hardy few do make the lanes off the steps their homes, but as a strip of up and down green from the Embarcadero or thereabouts to Coit Tower with views and wild parrots and lush tended beautiful growth and smells, the Filbert Steps are really a magical spot for a visit.  

Then you'll come back with others at times when you have a little extra time and maybe want to work up an appetite for three desserts and a glass of whiskey.

I'll say no more.  Groove on the images posted by the others.  Great views, sublime climb.  Nice time.  Go.
author: Markus N.

description: Vow, I've lived in SF for many years and never heard of these steps. I found out about them from you, my fellow Yelpers. My friend and I tried these stairs last week and it was awesome! Great workout and beautiful views of our beloved city. Another hidden gem of SF.
author: Lisa J.

description:
Stop and smell the roses.  No, really, stop and smell the roses!!!

The Filbert Steps are a great FREEEEEEEE point of interest.  How often does that happen in SF?  I absolutely adore taking people up these steps and showing off the views.  I also enjoy looking at and smelling the fragrant flowers that residents of TelHi grow here.  Some are truly stunning.  

Take your time-- enjoy the walk, the views, the smells here.  This is a great way to see the city.  By all means, go all the way to the top of the hill and head to the Coit Tower.  The views get even better up there!  

I find that these stairs are a great way to burn a few calories of the hearty North Beach Italian meals I consume! (makes me feel a bit less guilty for devouring Tony's pizza slices!)

A word of caution:  These stairs are quite steep in places.  They may not be great for small children, elderly, or folks with leg/ankle/knee issues.
author: Andrea H.

description: I greatly enjoyed walking down the steps and seeing the beautiful homes and gardens.  It's best to start at Coit Tower on top of Telegraph Hill and walk your way down to Levi Plaza.  From there you can explore the Piers.  If you feel you're in top physical shape and you want to walk up, good luck because the steps are a bit steep in some parts.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Do it! Your legs will burn and it will be hard to finish. But do it. Great views and beautiful gardens lining the steps all the way to the top. (Even saw dozens of wild parrots!)

Definitely a unique way to see San Francisco. And it was even a nice quiet area to enjoy a beautiful view!
author: Kerry H.

description: Beautiful and relatively uncrowded set of steps that take you through the gorgeous backyards of people's apartments. If you love flowers, you'll enjoy this quick little stop. We came here to enjoy the view and found some beautiful bougainvillea here to take pictures in front of. We also stumbled upon Coit Tower, which we didn't even know about before coming. This isn't a must-see, but if you're in the area, I recommend it for a tranquil break from the city.
author: Katie H.

description:
Overlooked Gem of SF.   totally enjoyed this part of history, while getting a work out.   Did not know that places (along the steps) like Napier Lane still existed, like I went back in time.   It is ok to take you time along these steps, there is many things to ponder.   I was told by a local, who was walking with us, that the houses on the right side, are the original homes from the late 1800's, they were not ruined by the earthquake and fire of 1906.  sooo cool.  I am sure there were many more stories, but that is something you will have to discover when you visit.

HINT: the start of the steps is across the street from Levi Plaza.
author: Theresa A.

description:
Severe case of acrophobia, thought this would be a breeze.

Got really fatigued and had a panic attack about midway and turned back around again.

There are pretty flowers and it apparently takes you to Coit Tower.

10/10 would have nightmares for the next few days about free falling again.
author: Tom S.

description:
Beautiful Steps with Gorgeous and Scenic Surroundings - Enjoyable Walk! 

My mother and I walked down from the top of Telegraph Hill towards The Embarcadero via the Filbert Steps, on the morning of August 1st. 

After admiring the views from the top of Telegraph Hill and the parking lot of Coit Tower, we walked down towards The Embarcadero via the Filbert Steps. The wooden steps were surrounded by beautiful gardens, flowers and lush vegetation. There were also gorgeous homes tucked away amongst the trees and plants on the hillside, situated on both sides of the steps. It was a beautiful and scenic walk and I really enjoyed my experience walking here. The stairs were not touristy or crowded at all, and there were only a few other people there during our visit. I enjoyed the natural environment and relaxed, tranquil atmosphere. 

The stairs were steep and if we had been walking uphill, it can imagine that it would be challenging and a great (strenuous) work-out. I was very glad that we were going downhill instead! 

I would recommend a walk/hike up or down these steps for anyone looking for a unique experience, a fantastic and challenging work-out, and/or a peaceful walk through a beautifully natural environment.
author: Brittany T.

description: After lunch at Pier 39 and dessert at Ghirardelli Square, decided to try to squeeze in Coit Tower before catching the last ferry. On foot, followed the signs and came upon these Filbert Steps to get to Coit Tower. What a workout! Skeptical at first, but the steps did go past some lovely homes/gardens along the way up. There was one portion where the steps stopped and we had to follow the road (hairpin curve) to continue up. 350 ft ascent, 400-500 steps total. Once you reached the bottom of Coit Tower, the views are already pretty amazing. See my separate review for Coit Tower. Took these steps on the way back down too, a well-hidden secret path, and part of the city I'd never seen before! They should really consider dressing up these steps with either a painting or mosaic.
author: Michelle L.

description: Been here a while ago when it was dark! It was a good view, very many lights underneath. The climb isn't too bad, it's just a bunch of stairs. Worth the view at the top, definitely recommend!
author: Andrea W.

description: One of my favorite experiences in San Francisco so far. Free! Both because it does not cost a cent in that expensive town but also free for the sense of freedom you experience climbing those stairs! You feel like going to the moon while trying to reach the beautiful Coit Tower. It was the first time for my friends and I and was so fresh, green, we could see the wild parrots, the sea, the pretty houses, the quietness. Wonderful workout.
author: Carmen V.

description:
The Filbert Steps are a series of staircases starting at Filbert Street's east end, near the Embarcardero, and ascending Telegraph Hill. The base can be reached near Levi's Plaza, where Filbert Street literally ends at the cliff below Coit Tower. Nearly 400 steps in total take the visitor from sunny Embarcadero to windy Coit Tower in as little as a few minutes, or a leisurely walk with stops along the way to enjoy the gardens and views.

If you're expecting a Lombard Street-type spectacle, you'll be underwhelmed. It's more about enjoying a latte and thinking about that Italian cafe waiting in North Beach.
author: John H.

description: San Francisco is one of our favorite cities to visit because of all the great food, but with that eating comes a whole bunch of calories.  In an attempt to stave off too many pounds gained, we walk as much as possible everywhere.  On our latest visit, SF Yelp pal Rodney H. introduced the boyfriend and I to the Filbert Steps, which ascend to the Coit Tower.  Talk about cardio!  These steps are the ultimate Stairmaster.  I tried to count them as we climbed and I came up with 435, but I think that's wrong since I've heard that there are over 500.  Whatever, the gist is that there are A LOT of steps.  I hope that I burned off at least one of the beignets that I ate at Brenda's Soul Food that morning.  The reward is the view at the top from the Coit Tower and knowing that you made the climb while others drove their cars to the top; yeah, you rock.
author: Terri C.

description:
a lot of steps, actually came by here by accident, got off the tram and Google said to walk through to goto our restaurant. WELL now we really learned that san fran is hills everywhere. Again place was nice to look at, most of the gardens seem to be private, but that's it, nothing special besides alot of steps.

Again bucket list item.
author: James W.

description:
More Steps?  Cool!

These steps have the typical features found in other steps:  1) they have risers and treads; 2) they require more effort going up than going down; and 3) they provide the option to go up OR down.
What makes these steps cool is they are located in a place where there are numerous beautiful views of the bay, the cityscape, the buildings, and the surrounding gardens.  The tricky part of navigating these steps is to not linger too long gawking at people's houses and property.  There are many unique houses along both sides of the steps, and they are every bit as interesting as the steps themselves.
author: Ted Q.

description:
With all the stairs we did in SF, this by far my favorite! Second is 16th Ave Mosaic of course.
Located in the intersection of Sansome Street and Filbert Street. (lowest)
Parking sucks but we managed to find parking along Sansome Street.
Three sections of the staircases--Sansome St is the bottom concrete part, Montgomery is the middle part which is also drivable and the highest point is on Telegraph Hill where the Coit Tower is located.
After the concrete stairs, the whole surroundings shift into a jungle-like place. It was pretty!
Wooden houses with nice little garden, it was amazing to look at.
The higher stairs are steeper that heads to the Coit Tower (which is also drivable and has parking spaces.)
Three-story high reliefs of SF, you can even see the Oakland Bridge!
It was a great experience! Not only you're looking at the view and Coit Tower, you're also getting your exercise on haha. Such an adventure!
author: Laramae E.

description: What a hidden gem in the middle of North Beach that leads to one of the most beautiful views I have ever seen in SF! It's a little over 400 steps to get to the base of coit tower, but I would say the best view you get is between the first set of steps and the set of stairs that directly leads to coit tower. You will see a winding road and from there, you will see the most beautiful sunset and/or views of the SF skyline. This is a very quiet, residential area so it's very peaceful and let's you get away from the crowded streets of SF! Definitely recommend these steps, even if you're out of shape, there aren't a lot and it's well-worth it in the end :)
author: Malika R.

description:
I tried the Filbert Steps today for the first time.  There's a lot of them, and the vertical rise is about 350 feet (that's about thirty-five stories!).  I wasn't sure I could make it, but I was bound and determined to make the ascent without stopping.  

I made it without stopping!  

So can you!  Go for it!!

"It is not the mountain that we conquer, but ourselves."  - Sir Edmund Hillary  (Filbert Steps is my Everest!)
author: B. B.

description: A great part of any walking adventure in San Francisco. We took the steps up towards Coit Tower, and found that it offers great views of the city, as well as a nice stroll through quaint backyards. It's about 400-500 steps, and really isn't that bad as long as you pace yourself. There are plenty of landings where you can take a break and check out the view.
author: Ho L.

description:
Walk your way up to see colt tower and you will have your exercise for the year. No joke. you will be climbing up the stairs so much your gluts will thank you. Being an unfit person and a person who is used to walking on FLAT land, I took many breaks during this journey. SF is known to have steep hills and this is just one of them. if you have a fear of heights, take the easy way up because looking down will make you dizzy probably. Luckily for me i am not afraid of heights so it was a wonderful view for me. the top is rewarding.

IF you didnt read my review, please do know these points:
DO bring a bottle or water or maybe 2...
DO take your time...
DONT GO if you have height issues
author: Bei T.

description:
I found the Filbert Steps by accident, and climbing up them ended up being one of the highlights of my trip to San Francisco! Funnily enough, Google Maps counts the steps as being a road (for pedestrians), so if you have the map set on walking, it'll lead you to this. Actually, the steps are indeed considered to be a "street," and there are even cross-streets and lanes as you ascend the stairs, where people live. I couldn't believe that so many people live at the top of so very many steps! Their views are definitely worth it though - as you climb up all these stairs, the view gets better and better. Even before you reach the top, seeing the bridge and the bay peeking out from the lush green trees is so rewarding. There are also plenty of lemon trees growing either wild or in people's yards. It's very quiet and peaceful going up here, a lovely break from the city below. 
Once you reach the top, there is a place to sit, relax, and look out over the stunning views of the San Francisco Bay, with the bridge in the background. I was lucky enough to make the climb on a very clear day, and the views were amazing. You also have the option, now that you're there, to go up even higher into Coit Tower (it is $8), but I myself chose not to, as hiking up the steps and seeing the views that were already right there was already awesome. 
Also, if you aren't too worried about where you'll end up, you can hike down on the other side of whichever way you came up, for even more new scenery on the way down.
I definitely recommend doing this in San Francisco! At 400 steps to the top, you'll feel like you've just been on a hike. :)
author: Jordan T.

description:
If you're looking to get to Coit Tower from Embarcadero, here is your way to get there.  There are many steps to get to Coit tower....I think about 400+ steps.  The difficulty is average, but if you get tired, you can always take a break along the way or tell whomever you're with "let's take a picture".  Trying to hide the fact that you're out of breath and about to pass out.

Along the path you will go through several "apartment/homes" backyards, which are  well maintained.  Their HOA must be crazy high.  

I admit this is the nicest way to get to Coit tower from Embarcadero.  The view is beautiful.

411:  During the day it's easy to walk these stairs, but at night there are no lights so a flashlight would be recommended.
author: Rachel B.

description:
What a workout! 

Thankfully, these stairs were constructed wide so if your sad, out-of-shape ass needs some rest, there's plenty of room (and railing) for you to hunker over panting and wheezing like a dog in heat, while other MUCH more fit people three times your age pass you by and look at you funny.

....Not that that happened to me.....
author: Josephine L.

description:
We walked up via the Greenwich Street stairway, so we decided to go down the Filbert Street stairway.  From Coit Tower head over one block to Filbert St.

Walking down the stairs wasn't as nice as walking up on Greenwich St.  Cute homes anyway you look at it.  And nicely tended gardens.  

As we were walking down to Sansome Street there were a couple of residents with their purchases in hand walking up.  Poor things.  We also saw a runner midway catching his breath.  Great quad training.  

My suggestion is that you walk up Greenwich and come down on Filbert to make a loop.  

Stairway bucket list - checked off Filbert St and Greenwich St.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Staring at the stairs makes you wanna turn around and stick to the flat ground but something about stairs that always draws me in I guess I love the unknown plus it really looks like a secret passage way. First few steps was like ok this isn't bad but if your out of shape like me the next 20 steps I'm gasping for air and grabbing the rail. I had to keep my cool because I had
This old timer in front of me climbing the stairs like a boss lol. After crawling that seems like 1000 steps I made it to the top And I can honestly say it was worth the sweat and pain. I said to myself the people that lives here must be in shape. The condos and apt here are nice and kept clean. Must be nice to have a breath taking view every time they wake up. If your planning to check this place out its worth it but don't be mad if the stairs kicks your behind.
author: Timothy E.

description:
So San Francisco.

So magical.

Walking up these steps on a perfect San Francisco day - as the sun peeked through the lush foliage that grazes the path along this majestic incline - was one of the most poignant ways to enjoy San Francisco.

Each couple of steps I would turn around to gaze across the stunning city. 

Each view got more spectacular - the higher I climbed.

Filbert Steps makes me fall even more in love with San Francisco.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I was feeling slightly underwhelmed by some of the sights in SF until I climbed the steps to Coit Tower. Totally worth the sweat and huffing and puffing (ooh somebody needs to hit the elliptical!). Not only is the view from the base of Coit Tower breathtaking, but the walk along the way (I took Filbert up and then Greenwich down) is stunning. It amazes me how people can pretty much live anywhere and how amazing it must be to wake up to such a view. 

A MUST-DO!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The Filbert Steps are a great San Francisco diamond in the rough! At first, it was a bit difficult to find-- the key being to to follow a small doesn't-look-like-a-side-street side street that roughly connects with the Coit Tower walkway that pours onto the street. Then, follow the street (I think it's Darrel) across another street and down a few flights of stairs, and then you're there. The streets are actually nicely labeled on Google Maps, though the Steps are not. The locals also don't know what you're talking about when you say "The Coit Tower Steps," so use correct terminology if you find yourself there and lost.

We came because the place is supposed to be endogenous to parrots. Though we heard them (or some other birds) screeching around in the canopy, we didn't see them. Still, the Steps are awesome because they are lined with houses (don't try knocking-- based on the signs we saw, they don't much appreciate entertaining curious tourists), and dotted with street signs. Proceeding down the steps leads to a beautiful garden right off of Napier Lane. The Steps end with a long staircase that leads from the brush into a small street that connects to a plaza with a Levi's store.

Would definitely recommend starting on the Coit Tower side and working DOWN the steps, as the final staircase is pretty long and steep.

It's awesome that it is free and it seems so randomly placed, adding to the quintessential quirky San Fran experience. I will definitely come again in my next City visit.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Decided to check out the Filbert Steps at Telegraph hill on a beautifully sunny afternoon. After leisurely strolling through the North Beach area we happened upon a small art show in Washington Square Park before finally arriving at the top of Union street, yes a bit of a hike, but the view of the city was well worth it.  The stairs were a bit difficult to locate at first but after noticing many people walking left down Montgomery we decided to follow the herd. Alas, we stumbled upon the heavenly peaceful and well-manicured gardens that surround the Filbert Steps. As you descend the steps (400 of them according to what I have read) you are greeted by the sound of chirping birds, friendly house cats, and a peek into the Eden like front gardens of some charming homes. Trumpet flowers, lilies, fruit trees and vines all grow in abundance that you almost believe you are no longer in the city. It is plain to see that the owners as well as dedicated community volunteerism has helped to keep this jewel well cared for.  So let's all respect the garden and the steps so that we can continue to appreciate such wonders within our great city. 
We did not climb back up but I imagine it would not be the faint of heart so be prepared for a bit of a hike. However,  in my opinion well worth the experience.  Once you get to the bottom you are not far from Pier 33, the wharf and ferry building. There is also the Coit Tower not far from here where you first go down the steps, you can take an elevator to an observation deck up top with 360 degree views of the city.
author: Dennis L.

description: For a 15 minute walk up series of residential stairs through a lush woody hill, you end up at Coit Tower, which has a breathtaking view of the golden gate bridge on one side, treasure island on the second side, and alcatraz island on the third. On the way down, pass by Pioneer Park and take in a panaramic view of the SF houses, chapels, and buildings. I wish the hike had been longer but if you start at Cupid's Span at Embarcadero, that's a good 40 minute walk along the the bay and up the filbert steps.
author: Shelley C.

description:
I've run them like a local, i've done them at a clip for the old ticker, and I've walked them like a tourist. Last Thurs, I was walking them at sunset in a frigid haze, and using them to keep me warm, as it was cold en route to Coit Tower from the Ferry Building a pied!!!

Lost in listening to a new friend's travel tales of debauchery and woe, I have forgotten about the slope of this incline. Good for ya.. winded at the top!

I've read Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill; as well, have viewed the documentary that was produced. Lovely association when my feet tread this path... it's just awesome. SF is full of magical climbs like this. I'm lucky enough to have done at least a dozen stairways in the City. Oba!!
author: Jana C.

description:
One of my favorite parts of the city and something I enjoy on every visit to San Francisco. After walking along the waterfront, I turn in at Fog City Diner and head to the Filbert Steps. Such a beautiful, lush, wild part of the city as you climb the steps and listen for the parrots of Telegraph Hill. 

If you are lucky, you'll see the birds. Even if they are being shy, you can still appreciate the steps as a good workout as you climb past artwork, flowers and adorable apartments with wrought iron gates that allow you peek-a-boo views of the bay.

When you arrive at the top of hill, you are at Coit Tower. On a clear day, or at sunset, the views are amazing. Then down the other side of the hill to North Beach where you can enjoy all of the amazing bars, restaurants and Italian bakeries. After this little urban hike, you can indulge guilt free. Pass the cannoli!
author: Jen K.

description: Fun little stroll. View from the top at the base of Coit Tower is ok; try walking down on the north side toward Little Italy, best views!
author: Matthew F.

description:
We went to Filbert Steps in search for the green parrots of SF. Unfortunately,that was dubbed mission unaccomplished , but we still discovered some pretty awesome sites along the way. 

To my surprise, it was about a 30 minute walk up and it was EASY!! This is coming from someone who hasn't worked out in over 8 months. There was a ton of beautiful homes and greenery. It was like a forest in the city with amazing views at each stair break. It's an incentive to just keep walking up in addition to view point and a landmark (Coit Tower). I still keep dreaming about how it would be like to live there --minus the moving in part. what a workout that must be.

There is parking at the bottom that cost 25 cents per 8 minutes and has a 2 hr limit and Credit card meter which gives you more than enough time! We also walked over to Fisherman's wharf to get some clam chowder after! It's a lovely place to enjoy on your day off.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Such a cool gem right in the city. These steps are steep, but surrounded by gardens and peek-a-boo views of the city make it worth the trek. 
I walked from the Embarcadero to Coit Tower in about 40 minutes (with stops for photos and to catch my breath a couple of times). 
Will definitely bring friends/out of town guests here for a SF hike!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Be in shape to go up these stairs and have the "Eye of the Tiger" on your playlist for inspiration.  DO.IT.  These steps led directly up to Coit Tower and if you keep on going you will hit North beach on the other side.  You will see the famous SF parrots on this trek and spectacular views of the city.  

If you are a tourist you definitely should do this, it is free and it takes you straight to Coit Tower which is another landmark that costs $8 to go to the top.  Another plus is that after that you can continue to the other side and end up in North Beach and rest at a cafe and people watch.
author: claudia w.

description:
I didn't realize these steps had a name, but hey its a nice place to take pictures and to jog the stairs.

The path also leads to Coit Tower going up hill, going downhill I think it lets to some barracks. I remember when taking pictures here lots of greens, an old cabin and you getting in the way of joggers when you want to pose near some plants.

Walking on some old wooden steps is cool, feels like cambridge Oregon. Local flavor for a quick experience. Heres a quick tip: on a downhill walk, look like your surfing, I did and it look like it!
author: Jon B.

description:
Love.  I worked at the base of these stairs for a little over a year.  Wonderful lunch workout and sunset view apres-work.

On weekends,  this is a popular way to get to Coit Tower, or at least it seemed that way on a Saturday morning 9am trek.

You may see the famous green parrots or a few locals whose homes are literally along/on the path of the stairs. 

Start your walk along Embarcadero, cutting thru Levi Plaza or around Green Street. 

Wear comfy clothes and bring a camera. Ahh writing about this makes me want to plan another day out walking these stairs and down into north beach.  :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Beautiful views on your way to Coit tower. There's parakeets too! Randomly awesome!
author: Emyli V.

description:
After a picnic at nearby Levi's Plaza, we worked off the sourdough calories by climbing the Filbert Steps, a narrow pedestrian pathway of 377 wooden stairs to the top of Telegraph Hill.

Telegraph Hill was originally the site of a visual telegraph station (semaphore) used to alert residents to the arrival of ships.  The steps were constructed so Italian fishermen and dock workers could commute on-foot to the wharves from their North Beach homes.  Recently, Telegraph Hill has been populated by a loveable flock of wild South American parrots.

We searched in vain for the parrots, as we climbed past charming homes and colorful gardens.  At the top of the hill, we all but forgot about the birds as we admired Coit Tower (closed for renovation), and sat mesmerized by the view of San Francisco Bay.  Suddenly, we heard a loud shrill squawk, and then witnessed an impressive fly-by of about one hundred olive green parrots with cherry red heads.

The Filbert Steps star as a beautiful passageway to the top of Telegraph Hill.  Stars are also deserved for being a stair-master substitute, uncrowded access to Coit Tower, and wild parrot sanctuary.
author: Joe R.

description: One of my favorite parts of the city. If you're able to/don't mind climbing a lot of steps, these are great! Beautiful flowers and quirky little houses (turn onto Napier Lane to see more) on the way up to Coit Tower with incredible views. No need for a gym pass when you've got these steps-- and it's free. :)
author: Fiana L.

description:
Pretty much the best way to get to the Coit Tower from Embarcadero is up these 600 steps.  Well, at least I think there are 600 steps.  That was what someone told me today when I asked them for directions.

Anyway, Filbert Steps consists mostly of wooden steps and some concrete steps at the beginning and end of the route.  It's pretty steep and narrow, but you'll get a great workout and will pass an interesting array of houses that are strategically hidden behind trees and bushes.

I saw quite a few number of people going up these stairs to get to the tower so don't feel scared even if it does seem lonely at some point.  Just remember that the Filbert Steps is made up of SEVERAL set of stairs.  They are broken up in several places by cross streets, but to find the connecting stairs is an easy task. 

I only went UP Filbert because I took another set of stairs down to get back onto Embarcadero.  I think my legs had already turned to jello so it was a good idea I didn't go down Filbert.
author: May W.

description: The best way to work off that clam chowder that was oh so good!!  Beautiful view at night.  The stairs are fairly well lighted but there are some darker sections.
author: Rob R.

description: After reading how strenuous the steps are I almost avoided these. But they happened to be mid way on my walk from FiDi to Pier 39 so a climb seemed inevitable. It actually wasn't all that bad, stopped once or twice pretending to use my Smartphone, to catch a breath. Nice views on this clear afternoon, however the tower is currently closed for construction.
author: Ute L.

description:
The Filbert Street Steps run along a short section of Filbert Street, along which is a garden tended to and paid for by the residents of the street. The steps lead from Telegraph Hill down to The Embarcadero. Many houses in this residential neighborhood are accessible only from the steps. Similar to paved streets, several fire hydrants and a solitary parking meter are located along the steps.

For me climbing up and down these steps has been an optimum form of Therapy. When life has  thrown me a knuckleball, I'd rather be concentrating on my breath while exercising than wasting money on a psychologist who want to know more about my Mother. It's also cheaper than Bikram Yoga, and all I have to do is remember to put one foot in front of the other on each of those 482 steps. It's a great workout and there's always something insightful that I've thought about along the way. It's not quite the Camino de Santiago, but it's close enough. 

The gorgeous payoff going up is Coit Tower, the view from the top of the Telegraph Hill world, and maybe the Parrots.. Then it's downward to North Beach for Italian pastries, refreshments at Cafe Trieste or a wide variety of dinner choices with friends.
author: Eric B.

description:
Filbert Steps are a martha focker! Absolutely beautiful, but a martha none the less! 

Give me the Vallejo steps any ol' day. Better yet... Give me that 1.2 million dollar house the oldman and I checked out (at a much-needed break...uh, Open House) about half way up to Coit Tower. 
 
And, I have never been more jealous than I was walking UP from the very first steps, all the way up to Coit Tower, at all of the smarter folks walking DOWN the steps! We weren't even trying to see Coit.

The oldman told me we were going to go see some wild parrots. I was really looking forward  to dodging parrot poop! But, alas the parrots weren't flitting about that day; I probably scared the shit outta them with all of my huffing and puffing, and muffled curses. 
But, that's okay. I got to get in some exercise, visit SF Barbie's dream home, and watch the bathroom at Coit Tower clean itself. Bathrooms really shouldn't clean themselves; they don't do a very good job. I'd rather be a parrot and have the world be my toilet.
author: Kara B.

description:
The best, less-known place to see and walk in San Francisco. Terraced gardens, flower-scented air, canopied mini lanes,  entry pathways arched with gnarly trees, panoramic views, rose gardens, unsighted elves and pixies, and a exhilarating workout all the way up to an SF landmark.

A wooden stairway to heaven. 

Never will you "drive" up to Coit tower again.
author: Umair K.

description: This is a cool little walk between Coit tower and the street level. If you don't want to get sweaty, I suggest you walk down instead of up - it's quite a workout to climb to the top! It's cool to walk through what seems like a secret garden.
author: Ross L.

description: A beautiful climb to see SF Bay from up top. Ends at Coit tower.  Goes through the backyards of a very cool neighborhood on telegraph hill, beautiful roses, plants and tree canopies.
author: Rebecca S.

description: A well maintained escape and journey from one part of the city to another. Thigh blaster au'naturale!
author: Regina D.

description:
Did the steps on a Sunday and it was not crowded at all. It was a hot day so it was a good workout and the shady portions were a great relief. Parking wasn't too hard to find at the bottom.

The houses on the way up are the best. I couldn't imagine doing a Costco trip and the nunloading into one of these homes. They are so quaint and feel so homey.

Once at the top, Coit Tower awaits. The walk down is not bad either.
author: Steve V.

description:
Done.

Walked from Jackson/Davis to Sansome/Filbert, up the Filbert Steps to the steps leading up to Coit Tower, walked around the parking lot, down the Greenwich steps to Sansome, back to Filbert again, and up the Filbert steps to Montgomery. 

From Montgomery to the steps at Green/Montgomery, down these steps, walked over to Montgomery/Vallejo, up these Vallejo steps to the top, then back down to Montgomery, back to Jackson/Davis. 

That's about walking 1.9mi in 40min.
author: qirk z.

description:
Likes: I came here over a year ago and totally forgot to review this place, but it's a pretty little hidden place.  Get ready to walk up a lot of stairs and on the way you can see some pretty greenery and flowers of the residential houses. 

Dislikes: It's not WOW but more of a place to go if you're bored and want to take a walk with a view
author: Karen M.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF. I love these steps -- they are the best part of visiting Coit Tower. Be prepared for a mini-maze sweaty workout that takes you through a series of beautiful, lush secret gardens and homes until you catch the glorious views from the very top. The most amazing part is that this gem is located near so many of the busiest parts of the city. When you get to the bottom, you are spit right out into reality onto the Embarcadero, so it is very accessible by public transit, and walking distance from the Ferry Building and all those restaurants. The top is walking distance from Washington Square Park and all the neat spots in North Beach.
author: Cynthia W.

description: Clearly you are researching these steps, so you have some idea of what you're in for. We on the other hand stumbled upon them and thought that is how you get up to Coit Tower... a quarter of the way up, a few locals asked if we were "GOING ALL THE WAY UP"!!!! That should have been our first clue... Half way through we were winded. And by the time we reached the top our legs were jelly. BUT it is an awesome jaunt and the houses are really neat to see and you can hear those wild parrots! Yeah I'd do it again!
author: April G.

description:
I have always read about Filbert Steps, and so finally, we decided to trek up them. Parking can be found on the street at the bottom, it is metered, so pay up unless you want a ticket. 

The Filbert steps starts off pretty steep, but become easier. They are also covered by trees and it appears to be somewhat of the neighborhood's backyard. 

About halfway is Telegraph, so you can snap a few shots on the streets overlooking great views.  

Continuing on the steps leads you to Coit Tower. 

Fun little trek starting from Levi's Plaza and ending with Coit Tower.
author: Roger A.

description: What a joke - everyone calling these a "hidden gem" or "relatively unknown". Well, they USED to be. And they also USED to be a lovely, relaxing way to get down to Levi Plaza from Coit Tower. Now, thanks to social media, they're jam-packed from dawn to dusk with hordes of tourists who stand in the middle of the steps taking selfies, and hard-core "me-first" Rambos who think it's their God-given right to run everyone else off the steps. Do yourself - and the poor people who live on the steps - a favor. Walk up to Coit Tower on Filbert Street from Columbus Avenue, admire the view, and walk back down the same way. If you MUST go up or down the steps, please try to be aware of the fact that there are other people around you, don't stop en masse on the steps, be quiet and respectful of the residents, and don't use their yards as ashtrays.
author: Steve K.

description: If you are walking, this is the best way to get down from Coit Tower. Going up may be a bit of a challenge, but would definitely be a good work out!
author: Abby S.

description: Beautiful hidden jem of Sanfransico, lush and green. Definatly a good workout, and backs up to coilts tower. It's very clean and we'll taken care of I would highly recommend.
author: Jamie S.

description: Just got back from San Francisco about three weeks ago, my friend Bob and Myself were walking and we saw a sign, it read Coit Tower steps, so we thought, shall we go for it, the answer was yes. Excitedly we started the long climb, but soon we realised this was a real challenge, our pace soon slowed to a crawl, stopping frequently for air, as we got higher our legs felt like jelly, they would not respond, but we were determined to finish what we started. A couple of other mountaineers overtook us as we gasped for breath, we thought we were reasonably fit, but perhaps not as fit as we would like, eventually we reached the summit, what a relief, but what a view, and a huge sense of achievement, what an amazing adventure, if you are thinking of trying it, please do, take it slow and enjoy the surroundings, beautiful views, pretty flowers, fresh air and fulfillment.
author: Martin N.

description:
Climbing towards the regal presence of the Coit Tower via this steep but picturesque stairway (400+ steps), you will be rewarded with sweeping views of the city and the ocean as you climb up higher and higher...  

At the end of the huffing and puffing, you will reach the Coit Tower, which is a great vista point. In a sunny day, you will see infinite expanse of the clear blue sky, the vast ocean, the Bay Bridge, the Alcatraz, and basically, just the amazing cityscape of San Francisco gleaming under the sunlight.

And you would pity those poor tourists who didn't know better and drove up to the Coit Tower AND got stuck in the (expected) jam near the tower! Dudes, leave your car below and CLIMB UP the Telegraph Hill! Beats getting stuck in a jam and paying for parking, which might even be nonexistent.  

Seriously, this stairway isn't as bad as I thought. Sure, it was VERY steep, especially in the beginning, but it didn't take us all that long to reach the top. I think we managed it in less than 15 minutes or so. Nice craftsman houses along the way - some cute, some majestic, some dilapidated. Lots of pretty gardens too! Lush and green. So spread the words around: the FILBERT STEPS is really the BEST way to reach the Coit Tower. Save your gas and walk up!

If you take public transportation and WALK, you might want to walk along the Embarcadero (start at the Ferry Building, for example), enjoy the sea view and the breeze, then turn left, and make your way to Sansome and Filbert where the steep stairway starts. You can come down from the Coit Tower via Greenwich steps, which would lead you to the North Beach or Pier 39/Fisherman's Wharf area. If you still have some strength left, return by walking up the Nob Hill and down to Powell/Market St. Of course you have the option of taking the touristy Cable Car back, but if you walk, rest assured that it would be a nice long walk, up and down the hills of San Francisco, burn a few calories while enjoying the views.

If you DRIVE, you might be able to find parking on Sansome. We found plenty of parking spots on Sansome on Sunday (meter parking is FREE on Sunday).
author: Rachel W.

description: I loved climbing these stairs after brunch!  The weather was perfect, there were great views along the way, plus even some beautiful parrots hopping in some trees.  Such great greenery and views of SF here.  I only wish they had stairs like this in every city!  Great outdoor workout (You can walk/jog up the steps, but probably not wildly - at least not during the early afternoons due to all the walkers/tourists).  I'd pick this over the gym on any given Sunday.
author: Cece Y.

description:
Free time, fresh air, views, joints moving -  the ultimate luxury!   

WHAT'S GOOD:
Hundreds of stairs, great views, gorgeous flowers and trees!  It only gets touristy once you hit Montgomery and again at the base of the tower.  

I like to climb these stairs up to Pioneer Park, then hike down to Little Italy for a drink.   The stairs have the perfect balance of shade and sun to go easy on the ink.  

In the morning, you will likely catch a group of Bay Club members hiking these as part of a class - that's pretty much how I came to love these.  Late mornings, especially on the weekends, these are pretty clear - especially on a nice day.  

I will share a few of my trainers tips below, just because it would be nice to see more people suffering these stairs with me: nothing tightens your gluts like lunges, squats and stairs!  So for you curious Bay Clubbers - this is what we did for "Red Carpet Ready":

7am- warmup 5 min jog on tread
stretch
1 laps around Bay Club
1/4 up steps then down
1/2 up steps then down
3/4 up then down
total climb then down
stretch and get your breath back
hydrate

if you want to go just for the view, hike all the way up is also a good workout.  

NOTE: Don't feel bad if granny and grandaddy pass you - they've been doing these stairs for years.  Also, either hydrate well before hiking or bring water because you will want to drink from the dog bowl midway up. 

TIP: don't forget to stop and smell the roses, turn around for the view, and watch out for the bees!
author: Rayna A.

description: Ahh boo.  I really thought these steps would be a nice little journey.  Wasn't a hard walk up at all and once I get on top to Coit Towers I was a bit underwhelmed with the view because all the huge trees covered the bridges and skyline.  It's nice that you can see the Bay Bridge (better view of this) on one end the and GG on the other but there's much nicer views of the bridges from other locations.
author: Kim D.

description: A perfect way to get some exercise, burn off some calories and get to the Coit Tower.
author: Mike G.

description:
We cleverly planned to walk up the Filbert Street Steps from our hotel on Columbus and then down the far side towards the Levi building, resulting in a short but steep uphill climb to the Coit Tower and a longer and more scenic descent to The Embarcadero.  This resulted in the hardest part of our day-long self-guided walking tour being right at the start - a MUST for folks like myself who get hangry after long days in foreign cities!

If you were to start this walk in the opposite direction it would definitely qualify as a pretty serious stair-climbing workout, and if I lived in San Fran I think I would make a point of doing it on the regular to improve my cardio and leg strength.  The steps are a total throw-back to old San Fran and really make you think about how this city of hills grew and developed.  I loved checking out the beautiful old character homes and amazing gardens along these stairs and think it's pretty cool that the residents and businesses all seem to take a lot of pride in being a part of this historic tourist attraction.

(4/30)
author: Monique B.

description: This place is so killer, there are parrots flying around and secret garden style steps. Found parking nearby with a sign pointing to the steps. Many plants grow all around and it feels like an old style the city of SF.
author: Dove N.

description: Best ~400 steps I've ever climbed. Believe it or not, it gets easier the more times you climb it. Regardless, it's a must if you're visiting San Francisco, or even if you already live here, you haven't experienced the real SF unless you've walked up/down these steps. Not only is it a great work out but it's also very beautiful. Feels like you're in a completely different place. I'm a bit envious of the residents here as they get to be surrounded constantly by all the lush greenery, flowers and birds chirping. Still, I'm happy to have these  hidden oases in the city that I can always walk (or run!) to whenever I feel like it.
author: HM N.
