description: Do the steps! Easy walk from the Embarcadero. Takes you up to Coit Tower. Gorgeous views while going up the steps. Maybe you'll spot some wild parrots. They are rumored to hang out here. Get a workout while you are sightseeing and take in the city a little slower, except for your breathes they'll start coming a lot faster. Whew!
author: Oulie T.

description:
I hate stairs so much but these were surrounded by lovely goodness :) I didn't even know about them, I just happened to say let's take this way not knowing the workout we were about to have.

These steps offer lots of great views of the city. The people who own homes there have great yards and cute statues. There were many pleasant scents to go with the sights. The parrots were hanging out near there too. Such a lovely place. I'd gladly go back to climb down them instead of up them :)
author: Laura L.

description:
Walked up these steps (after going up Montgomery) and boy I'm out of shape!
Dang how those people run up and down these steps. Kudos to them. Shame on me!
author: Nick L.

description: Almost didn't opt to go up the stairs, but our group of three is glad we ventured to the top. Nice gardens and beautiful views on the walk to the top to get to Coit tower.
author: L M.

description:
Pretty much the best steps to run in the City, minus the occasional blockage due to lolly-gagging tourists. Great workout with a great view at the top. Other top contenders for stairs to run in SF:
- Lyon Street Steps
- Baker Beach Sand Stairs (aka: Sand Ladder)
author: J. R.

description: Lovely way to get to Coit Tower! My friends made it sound like it would be a killer workout going up these stairs but it actually wasn't bad at all. The view was great! Lots of cute homes, greenery, and the city. I actually enjoyed the hike up these stairs more than the view from Coit Tower. I would definitely take friends here again! There's lots of free 2hr parking around so don't give in to the meters!
author: Sandra N.

description:
Wow, what a workout. Both a workout and beautiful path! Free 2-hour parking and awesome reward of coit tower at the top!

Bring water and watch your steps!
author: Eva Y.

description: I live within walking distance of Coit Tower and thus the Filbert Steps, so I decided to take this route to work one day. Whew! Let the burn begin & the sweating start! Definitely wear good shoes, comfy clothes, dress in layers for when the blood starts to pump and you sweat and definitely bring water. But oh my, you totally forget about all that when you see these breathtaking views. It is quintessential SF!! Such a great reward for battling the climb to the top. Don't miss this SF gem! Careful on the way down though, those who get vertigo or have a fear of heights will need to focus :)
author: Kristen G.

description: A hidden gem of this city. Love the views, houses, gardens, fresh air and exercise.
author: redtulip s.

description:
Warning, my review is tainted because I think San Francisco is a fantastic place to live in and one of the best places on Earth to vist. Climbing or descending the Filbert Steps is a must do in San Francisco. Obviously, San Francisco is known for its steps and hills and this climb is absolutely beautiful.  The stairs rise in three separate sections which is great because you can pretend to take pictures while resting at the top of each section. The ascension is wonderful.  Beautiful art deco houses adorn both sides of the steps, the gardens are colorful and well tended and there are turns, nooks and crannies along the way. The great thing about the journey is that world famous Coit Tower, one of San Francisco's most cherished landmarks is the final destination.

I would recommend bringing a sandwich along and stopping midway for a mini "bench picnic." It goes without saying that you should bring a camera because the views of the Bay Bridge, Treasury Island, Coit Tower and Levi Plaza are spectacular.
author: Chocoolate I.

description: Amazing hidden gem in SF! Not only are the views of SF, the Bay Bridge, and Golden Gate Bridge stunning, but the surroundings while climbing up the steps are gorgeous too. You'll encounter so much greenery and  flowers on your way to the top and the cool part is that you're walking right through people's backyards! And If you're lucky, you might see wild parrots as they're known to inhabit this area. Unfortunately, I was only lucky enough to hear them. At the top, you'll reach the Coit Tower and more amazing views of the bridges, the bay, and SF. It's an awesome place to sight see and even work out. We also witnessed someone propose here! I really regretted not bringing my camera along with me because there were so many good photo ops! I'm coming back when the weather clears up again just so I can take pictures. Hopefully I'll see some parrots next time!
author: Stephanie G.

description: If you go during right time of year there are wild parrots
author: John L.

description: If you want the real San Francisco experience, you have to use the Filbert Steps route to Coit Tower! You'll also get a little secret look out spot on your right, at the top of the steps before you turn left to cross the street to Coit Tower.
author: Kate N.

description: The stairs look unattractive at first but when you start climbing, you'll receive its a peaceful little slice of heaven. All along the trail, there are gardens and eucalyptus  plants. The smell is enticing and the view is amazing. This will definite give you a killer workout on your quads, there are more steps than i assumed.
author: Angela L.

description: Really a must see when in San Francisco, use the Filbert Steps to get to Coit Tower, and the reward is a beautiful walk and a great view over the bay and city.
author: Piet Z.

description:
I love these steps. It gives you an awesome view of the bay bridge and the sky scrappers of the fidi. There is also this small bench at the beginning of the steps where you can sit with your SO. Pretty romantic. I also love how there are these pretty flowers all through the journey up to coit tower.

It is also a very good workout.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I was a little nervous to hike these steps in my normal city uniform --skinny jeans, comfy shoes, layers-- but it was really no problem! We walked over from the Ferry Building after some blue bottle cappuccinos (for team morale) and started up the steps with determination. They're numbered in chalk (or they were when I went), saved me from counting!

Like I said, the way up really wasn't so bad and there's plenty to look at in the gardens of the surrounding homes. You're rewarded at the top with Coit Tower, and if you come down the steps on the other side you can look for the parrots of Telegraph Hill (We found them!). 

Makes for the foundation of a nice weekend adventure.
author: Alyssa G.

description: This is awesome, to walk amongst beautiful tended garden of flowers.  It's like I'm somewhere in the urban forest.  The smell of Jasmines.  The Aloe Vera actually has flowers.  Rosemary (note to self:  come and snag some sprigs of rosemary to cook Thanksgiving Turkey next time).  We had to asked the people who live there if they have to walk these steps day in and day out.  They do, but they have their shortcuts. I didn't count, but I don't think there are 600 steps.  Got to go back again.  At first I went to the wrong steps.  I went on Greenwhich St., not Filbert St.  Filbert is more heart healthy! and prettier on scenery!  But Greenwhich has better greenery.  I wish Il Fornaio cafe was open on weekends.  Their baked goods would be the perfect conclusion to the little walk.
author: Helen L.

description:
I learned of this SF landmark through my friend who lived in a basement apartment on Filbert. Though her bedroom had a rainy season stream running through it, there was no complaining the reasonable rent. There is a ton of Telegraph Hill lore, like the business atop living from film rights and the castle. I've received many parking tickets in the Hill 'hood visiting.

The charm of the Filbert Steps is their wild garden, maintained by the residents. In some wayback, the City of San Francisco planned a street right of way that was impossible to build for cars. On each side of the right of way there are residences. The "street" is now stairs and boardwalks, and a charmingly tended jungle. Mid way, head North to connect to the Greenwich stairs and onward to a path passing an old SF "earthquake shack".

Parking is terrible in the neighborhood, but more plentiful below off Battery than above.
author: Robert H.

description:
This place isn't just 400 (or so) odd steps. (my husband counted...but i think he got somewhat distracted on the way up by this alley cat who was posing by the tiger statue off the side of the steps) 

If it was, I wouldn't have rated it so high. But the reward is awesome cause you get great views of the bay on a clear fog-less day, Coit tower and an awesome work out. Plus, you could say you rocked 400 some odd steps! You also can check out some neat homes on the way up if you have that voyeuristic sense in you (well, if you don't now, you probably will when you walk up these steps!)
author: Marie S.

description:
How does one get the legs of a supermodel/elite athlete/action figure, while being able to enjoy some of the finest abodes in SF?  Win the lottery, get plastic surgery and buy a place up there.  

Since I am still waiting for my lottery numbers to be picked, with no whammys, I use the time that I would normally be spending my non-existent winnings on doing these stairs.  Some other stairs are at an insane incline, while some others are really more like a gentle slope, but this Goldilocks says these are just right.  

Plenty of places to stop and stretch, with a pulchritudinous view at the top.  Can't beat it.
author: Pam S.

description:
Just beautiful. 

My boyfriend took me here after brunch at Mamas. Finding parking during a Saturday afternoon is difficult but good thing we have a tiny prius. =) 

The homes here are breathtaking and the garden is gorgeous. I felt as if I was in a forest. There are lots of steps so I would advise wearing sneakers because my TOMs were bothering me.
author: Linda W.

description:
The most beautiful workout you'll ever have.

But...

it's easier to start at the top and go down.
author: Boots B.

description: I ran (most of) these steps one day trying to make it on time to a legal appointment; a real adventure.  Great!
author: Thomas H S.

description: Simply LOVED this place!! You can see amazing San Francisco and its roads from the height, the sea with ships, lights in the evening.. aahhhhh.. I want to go back again!!
author: Harsimrat P.

description: An enchanting hideaway from the city.  A romantic spot to adventure through with a loved one.  A workout with a beautiful view.  The only thing you won't see during your climb are cars.  Keep a lookout for parrots (not always on location, but can sometimes be found), humming birds, butterflies, and lizards.   Put this climb on your walking tour of San Francisco on the way to/from Coit Tower, the Ferry Building, Nob Hill, North Beach and Fisherman's Wharf.  One of the many little magical spots that makes San Francisco, the one and only San Francisco.
author: Jason W.

description: What a great workout! I loved climbing a TON of steps and taking in the great views along the way. Such a great thing to do, especially on a cool day. Ah...
author: Lili K.

description:
a must-do for any traveler to san francisco.

just bring a bottle of water and some comfortable shoes, because it is a HIKE to get up to Coit Tower from the very bottom. 

I tried looking up about how many steps there are, but couldn't find it. there has to about 500... i really liked how many different kinds of steps we climbed. its a weird thing to acknowledge, but there had to have been at least 4 or 5 different style stairs we climbed. 

that's besides the point... the steps give such a wonderful view to the beautiful city of san francisco... stopping and looking and taking pictures is a must. it's also great to acknowledge how good YOU have it to not have to worry about carrying groceries or a car seat up and down those stairs everyday if you lived in one of the houses along the steps!!

somewhere in the middle of the stairs is a little trail into the wilderness which leads to a bench, where i saw a smart and adorable couple enjoying sandwiches and conversation amidst the beauty, something i'd do if i lived in SF...

but, once you reach the top is a momentous achievment!! you are at the highest point in SF, and you got there, using your awesome self.

i gave it 4 stars because it was hard.
author: Ava M.

description:
I have serious baggage about stairs.  It started as some kind of phobia and has escalated in weird ways over the years.

A bit of background: I grew up in Chicagoland, where I was exposed to the terrifying(!) spiral staircase into the Egyptian exhibit at the Field at a young age.  I remain panicked whenever I have to walk on open-grate fire escape-style stairs, even now.  And stairs with an open riser make me SO nervous.  What's supporting those things?  Why aren't YOU scared?  And then ten years ago my wonderful white-haired super-sweet grandmother died by falling down stairs.  Yes, I expect to have a bit of stair-induced panic for the rest of my life.

So the fact that I planned to walk to Coit Tower from the Embarcadero area showed huge progress in my stair-related hangups.  I didn't walk up the Filbert Steps - I walked up the flight one street over (don't have me look up the name, please!) - but I walked down the Filbert Steps.  And let me just say, I'm glad I didn't walk up them, because that open tread wooden step picture that another Yelp user posted is giving me the heebie-jeebies just staring at it right now.

Anyways, it's not an awful walk down the Filbert Steps, even for the stair-phobic.  For the most part, it feels very solid, and it's pretty incredible to be surrounded by all that foliage in an urban area.  And when I was walking them it wasn't particularly crowded, so I could generally treat it as if I was climbing down the Half Dome cables and grip on to both handrails for dear life without feeling like a fool.

But I just about lost it on the last major decline.  You see, that part is suspended over some kind of abyss.  I'm pretty sure it was probably a 10-30' drop, not an endless gaping cavern, but to my eyes it was over the Grand Canyon!  And all I could think was "I bet this wouldn't survive an earthquake."  And of course at this point I passed someone taking the stairs as a workout and felt really sheepish on top of it.  She gave me words of encouragement, and I think those words kept me from being a huddled mess that refused to go up or down the last bit of stairs.

Here's the crazy thing: I'd totally take it again.  So if you ever see a gal curled up in a ball crying near the Grand Canyon abyss, offer a word of encouragement.  I'll need it.
author: Leigh G.

description:
You'd better be in shape to hike up these steps, but even if you are not, it is well worth the effort. 

The gardens on either side are a sight to behold, and the homes look like tree houses. How they even built them in the first place is a mystery to me. 

Coit Tower is the obvious destination, but that was just proverbial icing on the cake for this decades-long San Francisco dweller. The best part about the Filbert Steps is the gardens, homes, and the steps themselves.

A "hidden" gem. And another reason to be proud to call San Francisco my home.
author: Holly B.

description:
The best way to do these steps is obviously the top down.  But to be honest, it's not all that hard the other way around.  Certainly less work than walking up twin peaks, but I guess not many people can be bothered to do that either.

The best stretch is from Sansome up to Montgomery. The steps start out all steep and concrete, but then halfway up they turn to wood with gardens and houses.  It is like coming onto another world.  The climate is very balmy since it's shielded by the hill.  The lushness makes it feel so secluded.  I am really envious of these homeowners.  Although I still haven't figured out if there is a road or if they also have to hike all those steps.  If you then go down the other side towards Russian Hill the difference in climate and vegetation is very apparent.  Amazing.
author: Jean K.

description:
Cancel your gym membership and do these steps daily. Wow.

It's a great landmark to conquer!
author: Mari H.

description:
Some stairways are easier than others; some more well known than others. The first staircase we are going to meet, are the stairs to Coit Tower, which traverse the Telegraph Hill and North Beach area. I would say that these stairs are moderate in difficulty-about a 6 on a scale of 10. The stairs are in great condition and easy to climb, but, it is a climb.

You can start at either end of the stairs, ending at Fisherman's Wharf or North Beach.  We chose the latter, beginning at Filbert & Sansome Streets.  There are only about 600 steps on this staircase, and they are broken into three basic sections. The first are concrete stairs, meandering up the side of the cliff on the east side of Telegraph Hill, past secluded, idyllic homes, with beautiful foliage, flowers bursting in bloom and the scent of jasmine wafting through the air. The public garden, known as Grace Merchant Gardens,  is spectacular.  It is said that this area used to be an unsanctioned garbage dump. People would abandon broken furniture, trash and debris on the side of the hill.  In the forties, Grace Merchant, moved to this area at the corner of Filbert and Napier, and began a thirty year labor of love; removing the buildup and replacing the trash with flowers. She asked the city for a permit to burn the trash, and the story goes, that the fire burned for three days. Take time to smell the roses and keep spring awake in your heart. Take your time, look back over your shoulder to watch the Bay Bridge come into clearer and clearer view.  Along the route, you will probably encounter some wild parrots, which leads me to tell you about a wonderful documentary,(available on Netflix), called The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.  It is the story of a homeless busker, (street musician)who finds new meaning to his life when he befriends the wild parrots of  Telegraph Hill.  It is a slice of life that most of us will never see.

At Montgomery Street, there is a little median with a short staircase.  The third, (and final section) leads you to Coit Tower.  Once at the Tower, you can experience unparalleled panoramic views of the city.  Breathe in and enjoy. We chose to descend down into the fabulous, trendy North Beach, where at the bottom of the hill, you enter onto Grant Avenue, the heart of North Beach. 101 Music lines two corners, and although it is a bit pricey, it is well worth a look for buried, unique treasures within.  Being a fan of all pubs Irish, we wandered into Maggie McGarry's at 1353 Grant, indulged in a perfectly chilled pint and finished our perfect afternoon.

If interested, you can check out my entire review, history and photos on my blog: The Noise Beneath the Apple (dot) com.
author: Heather J.

description:
These steps will definitely help you lose weight. Forget getting a gym membership. I went all the way down to the bottom from Coit Tower then back up and I was tired! haha

While walking up the steps their are a few gardens. Very very nice and the views from the top of the steps are spectacular. Definitely worth the walk up and down the steps. Super fun and worth it! =)

Again just like Cot Tower you cant give this a bad review. Its just a LONG LONG staircase. haha =)
author: Daniel S.

description:
Feel the burn, enjoy the view.

The Filbert Steps is a great way to check out the Coit Tower if you are in the Embarcadero area. The first steps are extremely steep and your legs will begin to burn right off the bat, but after that, it's not so bad. 

You will see some great views of the bay bridge and the Embarcadero area.

We continued our walk from the Coit Tower, went to the North Beach area, then to Chinatown and back down to our hotel in the Financial District. I highly recommend doing this because it's a great way to see San Francisco without worrying about parking.
author: Jim K.

description: So, I climbed UP the Greenwich stairs and DOWN the Filbert Stairs. I was slightly more fascinated by the Filbert Stairs in that a) going down is easier than going up and b) it was really interesting going through what felt like people's backyards. The only time I did not enjoy the trek was at the point where the steps turned concrete near the end. I've got a weird phobia about staircases when you can see through railings and the steps. I had a few brief moments of panic until I stumbled upon a little kitty, just chilling on the steps. I'm not even a cat person, but it was kind of cute. What that little story has to do with steps? Not sure.
author: Renee E.

description: After twenty minutes of trying to find parking, I managed to nab a spot in a residential area. I thought we could just wander around until we found the Coit Tower. It's huge, how could we miss it? Then quite accidentally we stumbled upon the Filbert Steps and I have no intention of ever going to the Coit Tower another direction again. There are an insane number of steps but the beauty of the way is well worth it. The steps climb their way through hillside gardens and homes. The views are breath taking, but what really got to me was the peace of it. Its one of the quietest spots in the city. The smell of the flowers, the far off views, and the quiet really call for a moment to pause and appreciate this amazing city.
author: Kari G.

description:
Since the weather has been amazing lately I've decided to do lots of walking around town. The Filbert Steps is one of the best workouts for your legs and that little area right above them!

The best part of this little climb are the cute cottages along the way.
There's a beautiful little jungle of trees and plants. Everything from giant  Aloes to Rose Trees so take breaks and enjoy it. It's definitely special.

Of course the famous wild and crazy Parrots of Telegraph Hill come flying in  squawking back and forth constantly. They definitly watch you, it's oddly erie .
They're probably laughing at us silly humans trudging up steps and sweating while they can fly  .

Once your up at Coit Tower you can walk across the small parking lot and decend on the other side of the hill and end up at Washington Square in Northbeach and have a cool refreshment =icy cold beer. Hey I'm only human .

Definitely takes your mind off whatever might be ailing you and reminds you of the beautiful city that SF is.

It's basically a short workout but firms you up quite nicely when done regularly. Be prepared to sweat and definitely bring a water bottle.
author: Katherine N.

description:
Possibly the best workout of my life!

My butt has never looked so good. I recommend you run the steps behind me, so you get a full view. Only then can you truly appreciate what the Steps have to offer.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
OMFG, ME N BF ALMOST DIED!!!!  

I cant believe we actually walked all the way to the tower!!!  We found this place by accident, go lost in SF.  So we decided to check it out.  AMAZING.  If u decide to walk the stairway to heaven, dunt smoke before u go.. and carry water bottles, and DONT WEAR JEANS.  *sigh*
author: La La T.

description:
I had the great fortune to try my hand with en plein watercolors here last week with a watercolor society.  Beautiful sunny weather, lots of great foliage & color and you could also hear many tourists huffing it UP the stairs (it's much easier to go down kids).

According to the watercolorists, it's a difficult site due to lack of three key ingredients:  fore/middle & background subjects (and no place to sit).  Despite that, I went ahead and found a charming path lined with cut logs/stone & made my 1st attempt.  I'll need many more outdoor visits but will visit again & work on that painting!

There's also the Greenwich Steps too where the Wild Parrots movie was filmed...It also has charming backyards too.
author: Jen L.

description: Walking the Filbert Steps, up to Coit Tower is a unforgettable experience totally unique to San Francisco. It's a GREAT walk, one of the best walks in the world ... highly recommended for visitors and residents in the know.
author: Jim C.

description: Great scenic walk, especially for out-of-towners who want to see more than the usual tourist traps.
author: David L.

description:
Are we there yet? 

Are we there yet? 

Are...we...there...yet...??? (breathes heavily) 

So these are the steps that lead up to Coit Tower. 

When we first arrived at these steps only the first set are visible. They were nice but nothing spectacular. I was like eh this isn't nothing. 

Then when you reach the peak of the first step you realize oh they are called the Filbert STEPS for a reason. It goes up and up and UP! 

Once you are past the first set you are transported to a beautiful garden of flowers and plants. I didn't even feel like I was in America anymore but far away in some forest far far far away. It was so peaceful here. 

Even though the Coit Tower was beautiful the trek up there is worth so much more.
author: David N.

description:
"Are you going to RUN up those stairs??" The girl and her mother looked at me like I was insane.  I grinned back.

"Yep!"  I was quite enthusiastic in response.  Perhaps overly so.

Halfway up the stairs, my grin was gone and my enthusiasm, so bouncy in the beginning steps, was now dulled down to an aching burn in my thighs and the sound of heavy breathing. 

But you know what?  I felt good about it after.  And I have since gone back.  And I will keep going back. (Plus, it's an awesome butt workout :D)
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
Got attacked by damn PARROTS during my last night's run!

Cuuul!
author: Tatyana S.

description:
Coupled with my gym membership at BayClub (which conveniently happens to be across the street) these are a great way to burn calories and get your rear in gear.

First time i did them it was impromptu (brother was visiting and he wanted to get to Coit Tower from the Embarcadero) and I was wearing too-tight jeans on a sizzling hot day (FML). Rookie mistake- athletic gear encouraged!
author: Brianna H.

description: It's one of those magical places in SF. It's stairs and a garden at the same time which is a rare sight. You feel like you are in jungle far away from civilization. Also you end up at Coit Tower for a great finisher.
author: Daniel V.

description: This is the most beautiful view of SF ihave ever seen. Twin Peaks is a beautiful view of the whole bay, but the Filbert Steps are a beautiful view of Frisco- seriously the best. The steps themselves are incredibly steep. Before you know it your all the way up, but i would reccomend taking afew little breaks in designated areas before going up all the steps to really take in the view and catch your breath *you will be super out of breath* it can be hard to see the beautiful view when your just focusing on getting to the top. Couldn't imagine living up here and walking all the steps with groceries \O____O/ kudos to them lol. Its alot colder and breezier at the top which is nice when you've finished tour workout but you soon feel freezing once your no longer overheated. The view is truly a must see and worth every effort to get up there.
author: Brittainie B.

description:
Free treadmill -- no gym fees!  Just go up and down ten times and you're done with your exercise for the day... (Yeah I saw someone do that.)

Or start from the Ferry Building (after a bite at one of the many amazing eateries) and walk up the Embarcadero, cut across the park and up the Filbert Steps, then walk down North Beach (grab something to drink at Puccini Cafe) and catch the Muni on Market St home. S.F. has perfect weather for exercise!
author: Yvonne C.

description: Walked these steps last Tuesday and loved every step. A great way to get to Coit Tower. A very non-touristy thing to do in San Francisco.
author: Thomas M.

description:
One of the secret spots in SF that only locals would know about.  Who needs a Stairmaster when you can climb up and over Coit Tower/Telegraph Hill?

The most interesting part of the Filbert Steps is that there is a single fire hydrant right in the middle of the Secret gardens.  I can't imagine any firemen hauling that heavy hose up those steep stairs and managing to weave through the short canopy of the trees to lock into that hydrant.  Nonetheless, it's kinda quirky that it is there.  It's the first hydrant I've seen incased in its own wooden patio.  Find it on Darrell Place.

Second most unique thing you find along the steps are, of course, the "secret" gardens.  I am guessing the residents maintain these and boy! what a great job they do of it!  They're lush and green and when I was there many of the flowers were in full bloom.  The residents are creative using rock formations and picket fences.  Everything is just aethstically pleasing!

Speaking of the residents, their houses are unique in their own rights.  I love SF architecture with the Victorians and ornate buildings.  You will find Spanish inspired abodes here... painted in a faded orange.  I'd imagine it to be great fun living here and although space is limited, they make up for it in height.  If you do pay a visit, please respect their privacy.  Hikers, tourists, parrot watchers, and bored girls on their lunch break do frequent the steps... they must get annoyed of strangers on their front steps.  ;)

When you admire and visit quietly, really observe everything around here.  The steps are unique, but there are several other oddities to be noticed.  Those annoying parrots are everywhere here and fun to watch.  There are short pathways to kind of poke your head through. 

If you descend down to the Greenwich St Steps, be wary that these are very steep and may not fair well for those with height phobias.  My kneees buckled a few times as I crawled down.
author: Chris T.

description:
I am convinced that the people who live along the Filbert Steps:

1. Do not work for a living. The kind of money required to buy something like this and hold on to it is won or inherited. Okay maybe they do work for a living if it was inherited but I highly doubt it. They probably run the family business, also inherited. And
2. Do not own cars because god knows parking wouldn't be worth owning one. They probably have a car hiring service. See attribute 1. And because of 1 & 2, they have
3. Great legs

Number 3 I am ABSOLUTELY sure of because all through college I walked up hills/stairs like that and still have a smashing set.

So to the residents of the Filbert Street steps, I am highly jealous of you since your view is AMAZING. There are no words for what you are able to see out your window every morning. And the idea of waking up to the parrots sounds wonderful. I hope you thank God/Allah/Jehovah/The Universal Spirit/Your Higher Self/Your blatant good luck everyday for what you have. You should. 

And for those of you who actually do fall into #2, Go team light carbonfoot!
author: Alexis B.

description: The Filbert Steps rise in three sections from Sansome Street to Coit Tower, leading visitors past some of the city's oldest houses and the most sublime, sweet-smelling gardens, where you may spot - and definitely will hear - the famed parrots of Telegraph Hill. Nearby and running parallel to them are the equally amazing Greenwich Street Stairs. I recommend parking on Sansome - fairly easy on weekends along this primarily commercial stretch - taking one stairway up to Coit Tower for a visit, and then the other back down. It's like passing through an enchanted forest without the talking trees.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
I suggested this place to try for a group outing of an activities-based singles group and it was my first time trying it with them. I loved it :) 

It's this hidden gem in the city and I would love to come back again. Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. 

The group tried to see how many times we could go up as a group (I did 2 rounds since it was more for pleasure). You will start to work up a good sweat so dress in layers so you can dress down to a tank top or something. And if you want to continue the climb right up to the KOIT tower, the scenery from up there is beautiful too. I even saw these tropical parrots up in the trees there.
author: Mona Lisa M.

description:
Conquer the steps, and having bragging rights.
I climbed up this romantic path, lined with foliage and fresh blooming flowers with a gimp leg... and it was totally worth it.

You get pretty warmed up climbing it. Towards the top, you can leave the steps for a dirt hike and sneak up on tourists enjoying the Coit tower view.
On the way down, you can slide down the steep handle bars (if you dare)(and have good balance), it helps if you have leather gloves to serve as brakes.

Pretty view and  great place for active people. Great bonding activity!
author: Mindy L.

description:
If I could walk up these steps every single day I would be one healthy chica.  I do wonder about the people who live along the steps, I hope they don't have to deal with the smell of B.O. passing by their front porch every five minutes.  

So remember, if you walk up these steps do wear deodorant, because you will sweat no matter how slow you walk.  there are many many steps.
author: hanh b.

description:
I've never reviewed steps before, but I believe the Filbert Street Steps are worth reviewing. They are part of one of my favorite walks in all of San Francisco. 

I didn't find them on a website or in a book, but I was walking by one day, near Jackson Square and I saw the steps. I decided to walk up the steps to see where they ended.

The steps are beautiful. Wooden and charming, similar to something you would find in Europe, not in San Francisco, yet still with the breathtaking views. When I walk up the steps and look back, I can just stare at the view and the water. 

I don't want to ruin the charm, so I don't want to say more. Walking up the steps is great for more than exercise, it is great for reflection, exploring, or a day with a friend, romantic interest, or a spouse.
author: Christopher W.

description: Did squats in the AM before driving out to SF to fuck around for the day..had a couple of shots of Jack and a few beers before embarking on my ascent. Strike 2. Oh yes, I was feeling this about half way through. But for all my huffing and puffing, I thought B was gonna fall out. She was dying by the time we got to the first flight landing..worth the climb though. Nice views. You feel like you're in a jungle. Lots of foliage.
author: Morris D.

description:
Sweats rolling down my chin and I found myself huffing and puffing...asking myself, Am I there yet?

Filbert Steps may be new to you (those who are not tourist nor people who stay at Telegraph Hill...you know what I mean, couch potato?) but Filbert Steps has become part of life who I will see twice a day.  Why?  I heard you ask.  I'm glad you ask...here's why..

Founding myself staying at Telegraph Hill and work at Financial District, it will be ashamed for me not to walk down the steps and cruise around Levi's Plaza with my longboard.  It's all about going green people!  Anyway, let's not get carried away.  If you are new to the steps, don't look up or they will eat you alive.  Instead, keep your composure and relax...enjoy the view around you.  Let the mother nature take away your stress and relieve all the tensions.  There's only one thing should stay in your mind, to conquer the steps.  

There are gorgeous plants and flowers along the stairs which make the Filbert Steps so enjoyable to walk.  From time to time, you will see people jogging up and down the steps as if they are walking in the park.  Some of them are so focused that they forget to acknowledge that you are there.  Also, tourists are no stranger to the steps as you will see them stopping at the middle of Filbert Steps and taking pictures of the view or for the elderly tourists, taking a break.  Close your eyes and you can easily hear at least three different types of languages flowing in your ears.  Ahhhh...the beauty of melting pot.

Oh...by the way, after reading this review, if you happens to see a guy with a longboard going up or down the Filbert Steps, be sure to tell him that you read about his review on Yelp and I'm pretty sure he will acknowledge you and introduce himself to you.  So, what are you waiting for?  Get off the couch and off you go to Filbert Steps and head to Coit Tower.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Holy crap- This is what my friend and I tell ourselves every week when we wake up and run these stairs.

Nothing like running embarcadero, filbert steps up to Coit Tower, back to Pac Heights all before 7am.  

Why do I pay gym membership? Oh yea, because I would be crazy to do this run more than once a week- all my calves can handle. 

Talk about a high for the rest of the day...
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
From embarcadero, cut through Levi Square, past the girl meditating with her dog, past the waterfall, past the workers rushing to lunch, and you will find the humble beginning of these steps.  A few concrete stairways that offers little hint of the gem behind it.    

I came expecting a good workout, and was not disappointed.   It delivered a full server of 400 ass blasting steps with a side of tranquil garden, scenic ocean view, and even the occasional Japanese tourist with their SLR camera throwing peace signs.

Wish I saw the fabled parrots, but maybe next time.   I'll definitely be back.
author: Ben N.

description:
What great exercise!  Got my heart rate up to around 140. Helped burn off all that food I just ate at the Ferry building.

It was a perfect cool day, and not too many people.  Great views all the way up, and the best when you get up to Coit tower.

It's a good thing I had just sampled some chocolate at TCHO so I had some energy.
author: Stephen S.

description:
My 100th review goes to this local gem of San Francisco, Filbert Steps.  You can park your car along Sansome Street, and hike up to Coit Tower via the Filbert Steps.  It's not a super difficult trail, but I did found myself panting a bit along the way, and make frequent stops.  It's all worth it when you turn around and see the amazing view of the city, revealing more and more as you hike up further.

The most scary section, for Acrophobia (fear of height) like myself, would be the lowest section of the stairway that's made of concrete and steel.  Once you get over that, then you'll see the wide concrete steps running through historical art-deco houses and gardens.

Keep going up till you are close to the Coit tower, and then found the little garden that's right under the tower.  Lay on the grass, catch your breath, close your eyes, and imagine the world swirling around you...
author: Carina N.

description:
I'll take these steps over the stairmaster any day.

Great workout, beautiful gardens to admire along the way... I have yet to see a parrot however. Hopefully soon.

If I had to complain, it would be about the fact that I am incredibly jealous of the people who live along these steps... not only do they live in a garden paradise with an amazing view, but they also must have the most incredible legs on earth.
author: Christine K.

description:
One of my first days after moving to SF last September, my brother encouraged me to join him for his Pac West Bootcamp workout.  That night, they happened to be going to Coit Tower.  As I had no idea as to what Coit Tower was, I happily stretched and jogged my way over with the rest of the group.  I finished the workout 1/2 wanting to kill my brother for making that my intro to SF outdoor workouts, and 1/2 amazingly grateful to have seen that trek/view.  I went back the following Saturday to try and conquer them in a better way than I did on day one.
I have since done these steps a dozen or more times.  They get easier . . . well . . . a little bit easier.  But the reward is always the same.  An amazing view from the top (just ignore the tourists).  Take the time at some point to peek at the houses along the way.  They are ecclectic, and some filled with amazing treasures  :)
author: Linda A.

description:
I was really bored last night and decided to hit up Filbert Steps since it's been on my list for awhile. I wasn't disappointed at all even though it was so dark we couldn't appreciate all the little gardens on the sides. The flowers were blooming and we could smell every single one of them. 

We parked up by coit tower and walked down to Sansome and then walked up again. I could see how it could be romantic and all, but going at night made it a little more difficult to be walking down steps, enjoying  to the cute gardens, and paying attention to each other at the same time. Taking breaks to check out little alleys along the way make the hike up easier for us. 

If I could ever afford it, I would buy a house up here in a heart beat. I would come back here again on a sunny day so I could take pictures :) In fact, I would come back here on the next sunny day that comes along. This is why I love our city so much. There's a hidden paradise at every 10th street corner.
author: Kwan H.

description: Holy crap I nearly died on these steps - not a good idea to do this hike on the spur of the moment without the right shoes, a hat and maybe a bottle of water.  Aie.  Pretty gardens from what I remember... oy.
author: Shannon N.

description:
I ran into this by accident while trying to look for the Parrots of Telegraph Hill, and what a find! I had a great time looking at the scenery with a friend. Although, we didn't get to actually feed/see/take pictures with the parrots we did spot a few of them flying about.

Beautiful gardens and houses! Just make sure you pace yourself or you'll be gasping for air. =P

You can go all the way up to the top and go check out the Coit Tower while you're at it.
author: Joon Y.

description:
Of course I'm partial to the steps on my side of the city, but you can't deny the Filbert Steps are in a class of their own--leafy, bohemian, labyrinthine..."hidden gem" would be an understatement.  An apartment here might be the closest thing to European living you can get in this car-obsessed land.  Imagine having to take 300 steps every time you leave the house--and that includes taking the garbage out.  I wonder what kind of surcharge the movers have for places up here?  

Anyway, don't miss the Greenwich steps 1 block north.  Or "The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill" (available on Netflix).
author: Wes M.

description:
The steps are better than the tower at the top, one example of the journey being better than the destination. So many interesting gardens and flowers! It's good exercise and of course great views. 

I feel sorry for the mailman. Does he/she have to go up and down every day?
author: Ryan C.

description:
Lovely and charming.

Lots of green. Hidden.

Doesn't feel like you are in the city at all.
author: Judy L.

description:
Coit Tower at the top, Il Fornio (for cookies) at the bottom, great views and wild parrots in between.  What could be better?

One of those great San Francisco experiences.  Take out of town visitors up to Coit Tower in a cab or the 39 bus if they aren't up to the walk, then down the steps and a flat walk through the financial district to Market Street and the subway.
author: Bay G.

description: I stumbled upon filbert steps by chance, trying to get back home. Absolutely gorgeous views and so charming, a must see!
author: Marie G.

description:
Check out my morning commute!  I'm lucky to live at one end of the steps and work on the other, so I get beautiful views of the Bay and GG bridges each morning and evening, as well as a great workout. 
This is, apparently, one of the few places in California where you can grow lilacs.  If these are your favorite fragrant flower, as they are mine, someone's actually got one growing here!  For out of towners coming to ogle the parrots, keep going up and over the hill, keep going and get some lunch in nearby North Beach.
author: Kri B.

description: The Filbert Steps are an attraction?  I wasn't aware, although I definitely noticed them as I hiked up to Coit Tower.  Stopping about two-third of the way up, I turned and looked back over the city.  It's a striking view, with a slice of the Golden Gate Bridge on the right, setting a backdrop for the neat row of houses flowing down and up the hill of Filbert Street.  Of course, that's just a taste of the bounteous views to be had at the base of the tower, and then even more so at its top.
author: David R.

description:
Yey! I was finally able to see some of the famed parrots and not just hear them! Also saw a couple of them mating and then a rogue parrot broke them up. Haha. It was fun to watch. Too bad I didn't have my zoom lens that day :(

Filbert street steps! Each time I walk down them - I only walked up once. Walk down them if you want to just enjoy the beauty or showing them to friends from out of town. Walk up if you need a workout :D - I wish I lived in one of those houses along there!
author: Kaushal P.

description:
What is it you may ask? It is a long set of stairs going up the side of a hill. Then you may ask, are there dancing elf clowns throwing little pickles at you on the way up!? Unfortunately, no. Then you realize that drugs don't make everything better. 

Anyway the Filbert Steps are one of those SF landmarks that is more of a locals or repeat visitor spot. The climb itself is charming, serene even. This may even be a great exercise spot if you live close by. Other than that it is one of those things you should do just once.  

The first time I conquered the Filbert Steps was after a long night out. Luckily for me it didn't seem the bad but maybe I was impaired.
author: Lance H.

description:
Definitely a cool thing to do to ascend the steps (there are alot!) and check out the amazing gardens on the way up.  However it only gets 3 stars from me because at the top you reach tourist hell in the form of Coit Tower and it's army of ppl with DSLRs and huge lenses.

It's worth checking out at least once but if you want to avoid the tourists might be better off checking out the Vallejo steps and Ina Coolbrith Park.. less tourists and a better view (keep going to the very top past the park!).. though the gardens aren't as nice.
author: Engelbert H.

description: Great location if you love photography!  The parrots are definitely a treat but the flowers, greenery and views of the bay take your breath away.  Plus you're getting exercise.
author: Jean C.

description: For an inanimate object, you really know how to kick my ass. Maybe you should be a doctor, because you helped with my asthmatic self-diagnosis. 300+ stairs that wind through a beautiful floral hillside landscape should not make me loathe you like I do, maybe if you had warned me not to wear jeans and to have a bottle of water for the hike I would like you more. I have mad respect for you though, and I do appreciate the beauty that you reward me with at the peak.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Consider my rating the winter rating. I walked up the steps today and although it is lush and green with nice views of the bay bridge and full of squaking parrots, I didn't think it was super fantastic. The real treat was when you got to the top, to Coit Tower.......but that's Coit Tower. 

I do consider my review tentative as I can see how it could be 5 stars in the spring when everything is in full bloom. I'll go back for that.
author: Chris S.

description:
Gorgeous views. But very demanding steps. And I really detests the crazy green parrots. Yuck. 
But i'd Love to live on this side of the Hill...phenomenal views of the Bay
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I ran up these steps to exercise.  hahhaha.  jk I lied.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Really nice hike! Passes through a lot of quaint homes, wooden steps, domestic cats, huge trees, flowers! 

Its probably 300+ steps, and is a great place to burn up some calories.
author: Manish P.

description: These stairs represent one of main things I love about San Francisco. You can wander around and find something like this tucked away. A wooden staircase surrounded by trees and plants hidden yet accessible in a giant bustling city. It's almost how I imagined the secret garden when I was just a girl, except, well, you know, a staircase.
author: Emily C.

description:
Beautiful plant life and a good workout.

If I lived closer, i'd walk the steps each day as my workout. It really gets the legs burning. I also like stopping halfway and watching tourists battle the steps.
author: Adam C.

description:
My pal and I decided to try "urban hiking" and figured that these steps would be our first shot out of the gate. We're both in the "pretty plus" category and were HUFFING AND PUFFING the whole way, but we made it. The skinny folks sounded like they were going to die too, so we knew it wasn't just OUR out of shape asses. When we recovered and could actually talk again we wondered out loud about how people actually live there -- How much would it suck to come home drunk? Does the UPS man deliver to your door? 

Cardio and logistics aside, this place is one of those hidden gems that makes San Francisco the most beautiful city in the world.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Walked to Coit Tower after breakfast at Mama's and then walked down the Filbert Steps. After walking down with the gorgeous views... I had a better appreciation for the poor souls walking up.

We also passed a couple who were moving into an apartment halfway down the steps and my heart goes out to them and it looked like NO SIMPLE FEAT!!!


Beautiful place to go for a walk...
author: Annie M.

description: This really long chain of stairways leads up to the bottom of Coit Tower as you may know from other reviews. It can be tiring, especially if you start from the bottom like I did. This one runs parallel to the Greenwich Steps but is more crowded due to popularity. At the top, beware of cars leaving driveways. I find it unsafe at night how there are no street lamps. I see some small lawn lamps but that's not good enough. I mean, the ground isn't all that level in some cases. Electricity wires run pretty darn low and are wired in such a way that a fire can easily be caused. There is a fire hydrant halfway through though. I wouldn't say this is more beautiful than the Greenwich counterpart but it's definitely more lively. On a clear day, you get a great view of the Bay Bridge.
author: Dominic T.

description: Running up the Filbert Steps is like being in a painful heaven. This is one of those places that makes me love living in SF.
author: Jacob E.

description: One of those hidden SF gems.  If you take your visitors here, they will think you are brilliant (unless they are whiny outta shape losers that only want to go to Fisherman's Wharf).
author: Andi T.

description: damn these steps.....haha.  i was dying going up these steps with my bf.  He tricked me!  358 steps....felt like it was never going to end...but when you finally make it up tp coit tower....you will feel like Rambo....by the time we were on the top...we were both sweating like crazy...but so worth it....everyone should try it one time....our goal is to be able to do these steps 3 times up and down....there was a lady there who did it at least 3 times during the time we went up and down once. haha...i will see you soon filbert steps...and ILL BRING IT......
author: Sheryll D.

description: Oh what steps of Joy and Pain.  When I'm in town, my friend Dave always takes me on epic runs throughout the city.  My favorite is when we start in the Embarcadero and churn our way up the Filbert Steps to Coit Tower.  The first time I ran these steps I thought I was going to seriously hurl a lung.  But the more you do it, the stronger you get and I now look forward to attacking this climb (kinda of).  Once you reach the top you can take a quick gander at this glorious city before heading back down to street level.  We typically head towards Fisherman's Wharf where we can mock the fat sea lions lounging in the sun, and if they're not there, we'll make do with the fat tourists waddling through the Wharf.  Good times!
author: Dave L.

description: I lived two blocks away from here for over a year before I discovered the magical world that exists surrounding these stairs. It's like San Francisco's own secret garden. When I need to "get away" I come back here. They are also a great little workout.
author: Rose K.

description:
I first heard about the Filbert Steps on yelp as a way to get to the Coit Tower and man I am glad I did!  It is quite the trek to the top but the scenery on your way up is amazing!  It is fabulous and the only way to go!

It would probably also be a great place to workout too..
author: Stephanie K.

description: I just moved here from AZ and noticed these steps next to my new place. Since I have yet to join a gym, I thought I would go for a run in the rain and run the stairs. What a great workout! And so beautiful. I take these steps any day over the brown dirt mountains I use to hike in Phoenix. This is going to be a part of my daily routine. Yayyyy, I love SF!
author: Kelley D.

description: There is no earthly indulgency which cannot be cleansed by a trip up these stairs.  482 steps (think I'm lying?  count them yourself) take you from Levi Plaza to the top of Coit Tower (counting the steps at the top of the Coit Tower elevator).  Think of a trip up the steps as a three-day-weekend version of a trip to Lourdes.  And you just can't beat the view.
author: Ben P.

description:
The first stretch of the Filbert Street stairs, rising up off Sansome, follows the steep, exposed rock hillside of Telegraph Hill, serving as a reminder of what an architechtural feat San Francisco really is. After the first few flights, make sure to turn around and check out the Bay Bridge, Treasure Island, and Oakland across the Bay.
The stairs then enter a paradise of gardens that are so lush and sweet smelling it feels like you are walking through the Garden of Eden. It is easy to catch a glimpse of the famed Parrots of Telegraph Hill here; they are easier to hear than see, so listen for their raucous squawking. 
The final stretch of the stairs up to coit tower go up an island of vegetation that has been restored to (some) native vegetation. You will be rewarded with views on all sides, a cooling breeze, and of course, Coit Tower itself. 
The Filbert Steps continue westward, dropping you straight into the heart of North Beach.
This is definitely a good trek to show off the city to out-of-towners, or even just friends who've never done it.
author: Kathleen B.

description: This is a super late review from Valentine's Day after THE big pillowfight. I walked the Filbert Steps without even knowing it that night. We decided to walk from the Embarcadero to Vanness rather than waiting for the bus. It was a gorgeous night for a stroll. Little did we know that we would be huffing and puffing up those never-ending steps. I knew we were heading in the right direction (for the most part), but decided it would be nice to know how much more trekking uphill it would take. I stopped a fella' who was walking down the steps and asked him how much longer until we'd reach Vanness. He just chuckled and said once you get past this, you're almost there....you can do it. We made it bathed in sweat as well as a few stray feathers from the fight earlier that evening.
author: Carrie W.

description: Wow what a hidden gem. If you're up for a hike straight up a hill - do this! beautiful gardens, quaint houses, amazing views, & parrots! The reward for hiking up these steep stairs is Coit Tower and the amazing views from the top of the hill.
author: Kevan M.

description: Great views, awesome foliage, cool houses. Filbert steps has all this and a cool little bench about a quarter of the way up for you to chill, soak in the view and think about how lucky you are to live in this city. Had to take one star away though because the trees block what would otherwise be some spectacular views of the bay. Oh well you can't win em all.
author: Tommy P.

description: Don't come here with bears or out of shape people from the mid-west. Otherwise it's a great chance to get a bit of exercise while checking out a "secret" side of the city...
author: Quartknee K.

description: There are 384 of them. Am I the only one that has counted these? I can't be. It helped keep me focused while enjoying the calf burn and amazing views. Like others have noted, going up the steps is a great way to hike up to the bay side of Coit Tower from the Embarcadero area.
author: Julie F.

description: Amazingly cool spot and a great workout too! I love descending, looking at the bay bridge and saying Hi to the parrots. I wish the parrots would give us a schedule though so we know when NOT to talk them up and then take visitors and have them not be there!
author: Megan S.

description: My favorite places to bring out of towners from a local's point of view.  Start going downhill from Coit Tower and head to these gardens.  It gives a feel of the European Garden of Eden and you can't believe the quietness and sereneness of this hidden gem is tuck away in this part of the city.  And the lovely wild parrots of Telegraph Hill. Everything about this place gives you a calming effect of the city.   A must see for out of town visitors who doesn't want to do the touristy thing.
author: Chris C.

description: Not too long ago I had one of the nicest days in San Francisco.  After walking from the Embarcadero we decided we wanted to head over to Little Italy for pizza.  We found these amazing stairs that took us through lovely gardens and when we looked back there was an equally amazing view of the bay and the bridge. Yeah, the stairs burned but hey, it made me not feel so guilty when I ate the pizza.
author: Jovi R.

description:
It is indeed beautiful.  Definitely a work-out.  Great way to get to /from Coit Tower although if you are not up a lot of walk, you should take these steps down and never to go up all the way to Coit Tower.  
Nice thing to do when you have a moment to discover San Francisco.
author: Miinno N.

description: These steps are awesome.  I've walked from bottom to top and top to bottom before, but today the man and I just walked up Montgomery to Filbert and started up the stairs there.  I am so out of shape!  Just walking up the hills on Montgomery tired me out.  My legs didn't want to go any further.  The man practically had to drag me up.  Okay, not that bad, but I WAS tired.  I was huffing and puffing all the way up.  The gardens lining the steps are absolutely beautiful and the view is breathtaking (and not just because I was out of breath either!).
author: Kris L.

description: A great spot to hit when taking an out-of-towner on a walking tour.  It smells fabulous and feels like you're in a forest or park during the decent of the many steps.  Check out the parrots and crazy foliage.
author: ellyk E.

description: If I were named Filbert I would definitely want these steps named after me.  A demure tribute to our own Hanging Gardens of San Francisco, I am both watched and heckled endlessly by raging parrots flocking me higher.. higher.. higher up to Coit Tower, but yet I can't help but linger on my side of the fence to contemplate a Fibonacci succession of modest garden plots forming a continuous mosaic of speckled flora from base to summit.. an ascension filled with such sedate fresh air I nearly forget the fantastic vistas of Our Bay that lie a quiet distance yonder.  Wonderful cubby homes align each side of the narrow stair case, occasional bored orange cats sleepily strut their sentry walks, with Deco and Bogart both playing gotcha from the fronds.  Don't rush the stairs, the journey here is where most of the fun can be found.
author: Jim W.

description: I don't like going down on . . . these stairs.  Vertigo to the point where I think I see Jimmy Stewart dangling off of the steps.  But the workout is awesome...that is, of course, if you like to kick your own ass urban workout style.
author: Justine H.

description: What a work out!!! My ingenious colleagues and I decided to run up the steps as part of our weekly running club. It was killer but a great view from the top of coit towers. At least the scenery kept my mind off the pain.
author: Courtney R.

description: This place is great; enjoy the gardens and interesting pathways but remember to respect those who live there and try not to oogle too much over the parrots :-)
author: Michael P.

description:
Hiking Telegraph Hill gives you one of the best ways to sample the flavors of San Francisco. It is easily accessible from either Embarcadero (Ferry building) or North Beach.

For a suggested short hike, lots of great photos of what you will see on the hike, check out:

http://locomotoring.net/2009/06/13/birds-and-bees-of-telegraph-hill/
author: Mishti D.

description: Stumbling upon hidden spots like the steps is one of the things that makes you think a) damn this city is great and b) I love exploring.  The houses are beautiful, the steps are steep, the views are breathtaking.
author: Heather C.

description: Wow. Trying to jog up these steps was a challenge. I couldn't make it to the top nonstop. And the few other walkers there tried cheering me on. Brought my dog with me as well =) Nice walk (I usually go up the tower from the other side, this side was much more interestnig for sure) and felt really rewarding regardless of the journey once I did get up. Glad I finally decided to try this route up. I'll be back again soon! Hopefully next time I can make it to the top ^_~
author: Nhi T.

description: I would disagree that this is a "secret spot that only locals would know about" but that doesn't make it any less magical. Fantastic views, unique foliage, musty smells, and laughing parrots - the mystical gateway to North Beach. No wonder our supervisor lives here.
author: Eric ..

description: Views are worthy of the trek either up or down.  Your choice.  Note going down the steep steps is not easy on the knees.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Great excercise in beautiful surroundings....I love it!
author: Francis K.

description: This also one of my favorite places in the city.  I love walking up these stairs and looking at all the historic houses, the beautiful gardens and views of the city.  At certain times of the day (almost around 1P), the Parrots of Telegraph Hill show up and is that a sight to see. Good sights, good exercise, good atmosphere, and again, good for the soul.  I've been dying to rent a place here, anyone reading this that lives there, you want to sublet! :)
author: Meghana A.

description: This is a great place for getting a great cardio workout.  You will be rewarded with great views of the Bay and Coit Tower at the end of your hike.  It's a steep hike, but you can take breaks along the way.
author: John c.

description: Beautiful steps! Love the cottages along the steps.
author: tina M.

description: i totally love this gem! you're sure to catch some gorgeous views (on a clear day) as you make your way up the stairs.  just make sure you have your bottled water with ya as I believe the only water fountain is allll the way up at the top where the Coit is.
author: Syonora A.

description:
this place is really nice. i discovered it when i first moved to the bottom of the hill and thought we cld walk to north beach.  i brought my parents/family.

turned out to be a bad idea, since we weren't prepared for ALL those steps.  but also a good idea, b/c it's BEAUTIFUL (the gardens and the view).  i still wonder how ppl move into those houses and where they park their cars.  

gardens are really nice and the view is really nice.  it's a workout going up...i can't remember exactly how many steps there are (my sister counted)..but it is alot.
author: rien d.

description: always great, best at night, you can pretend you're a cat burglar.
author: Today Y.

description: Can't let a review of these stairs go by and not add to the general adoration... absolutely one of my favorite places to go. I try to go daily, as part of a long and lovely walk we take from our home in soma through north beach and back home. The stairs are the highlight. I've been there at all times of day and night and through all weathers. Every single time is magical. Completely corny to admit but absolutely true. If I ever leave SF, I will probably miss these stairs and their surrounding guardens the most.
author: Rebecca P.

description: Just a beautiful spot.  Feel very out of shape after the trek but that is my issue.
author: Misti L.

description: a good sanfran stairmaster routine training site for baytobreakers Hayes Hill stylin. vista takes your breathawayandleaves touristas breathless.
author: miriam b.
